B00003CXP1|5.0|Before seeing this film I had read all the reviews saying how fantastic it was.  Well, it isn't fantastic, and anyone that describes it is fantastic is highly disturbed.  For this is one of the most gruelling things that I have ever had to sit through.  It is explicit, upsetting and totally unforgettable.  But fantastic?  Jurassic Park was fantastic, this is on a higher plain.<br />Although the film doesn't really have a message to it other than 'drugs are bad', it thankfully shows both the highs and the lows of the drugs.  This is in sharp contrast to other drugs movies such as 'The Basketball Diaries' that seems to consist almost totally of lows.  It also shows that ecstasy, heroin and cocaine aren't the only forms of drugs on the market.  For example, the same cut shots and editing are used when Harry shoots up as when his mother switches on the TV, eats or drinks her coffee.  The point being that there are plenty of legal drugs on the market that have an equally destructive effect.<br />Finally, the explicit nature of the film: I found myself squirming in my seat a couple of times and there's no doubt that there are some pretty horrific scenes here.  And as for the incredibly explicit sex scenes, it's difficult to call them exploitive when they so clearly show the degradation that the character has gone through to reach this stage.  This film is not for the weak-willed.  It is upsetting and mesmerising in its sheer grotesqueness.  Yet it is also an unforgettable, important piece of film-making.

B00003CXZ4|5.0|Considering the undeniably interesting and original premise (guy with no short term memory goes in search of wife's killer) and the film's rave reviews, its perhaps surprising that this film didn't do better.  But then again it didn't contain Hollywood superstars, and before anyone mentions Blair Witch, a hugely successful (and fake!) marketting scheme.  More importantly, it's an adults' movie, which of course means that it can never be a box office success.  Although maybe those times are changing with 'American Beauty' and 'Magnolia' doing so well.<br />Anyway, the movie itself is told backwards.  Here the end is the beginning, the audience gets to see who Pearce took his vengeance out upon, and we backtrack to the beginning to find out the real conclusion.  This twist is ingenious, but makes for frustrating viewing as you try to grasp what's going on whilst watching the action at the same time.  This is a must-see-twice movie if ever there was one.  The acting from every quarter is wonderful, hopefully setting up Guy Pearce as a major star .  Come on Hollywood, the rest of the stars of 'L.A Confidential' are doing well!  Carrie-Ann Moss proves that there's more to her than rubber suits and special effects and Pantoliano gives a magnificent turn as Teddy.<br />So what makes the movie special?  Well, it's intelligent for one.  There's a neat little subplot that tugs at the heart strings.  Plus the director manages to extend empathy towards all of his miserable characters, imbuing them with life rather than using his supporting cast as mere cardboard cut-outs to help make the lead look good.  But what is the film about?  Any number of things really.  It challenges its audience's ideas of memory and its reliability as well as showing just how bland and easily forgettable most of today's movie fodder is.  This is a film to end all films: it makes you think, cry, laugh and sit at the edge of your seat.

B000055ZB8|5.0|I bought &quot;Nosferatu&quot; on Halloween night, to screen a double-feature with &quot;Shadow of the Vampire&quot;.  This turned out to be a terrific idea and caused me to wish, for the first time since childhood and my array of Star Wars costumes, that Halloween came eleven or twelve times a year.<br />&quot;Nosferatu&quot; may be 80 years old, but its influence is, amusingly enough, going to be eternal.  The &quot;Symphony of Horror&quot; special edition DVD is absolutely a must-have, with three audio tracks that basically create three different versions of the film, and with three excellent mini-features.<br />The basic audio track is an organ score derived from early-19th-century Romantic composers.  Married to the film's flickering tinted images, this makes ideal Halloween (or, indeed, any post-midnight) viewing.  The second audio score is more experimental, more modern, and much, much more fun.  Whereas the organ track basically lies underneath the movie and provides a traditional (if static) experience, the &quot;Silent Orchestra&quot; compositions give the undead film a new life.  This rock-jazz-classical track positively breathes in the way that Dracula never could.<br />The final audio track is the commentary by German film expert Lokke Heiss.  Don't be fooled by the man's voice and delivery, which is about as dynamic as balsa wood and interesting as an American cheese sandwich on white bread.  He cites both scholarly film treatises and Stephen King as he discusses Murnau's influences, the film's light-dark composition, and the use of mirrors and windows within the movie.  This is a terrific commentary track in that it increased my understanding of the move ten-fold.  Pity they couldn't have had someone with an actual voice (like Christopher Lee) read Mr. Heiss's words.<br />The featurettes range from cute to weird.  Weirdest is the &quot;Nosfera-Tour&quot;, ten minutes worth of home movies narrated once more by Heiss (oy vey) as he presents pictures ofwhat the film's &quot;Wisborg&quot; looks like in the year 2000.  The &quot;Phantom Carriage Ride&quot; is very eerie, spotlighting as it does one of the truly *bizarre* moments in the film.  Finally, the art/photo gallery is splendid, one of the best galleries I've seen on a DVD.  The real treasure comes at the beginnng -- the charcoal drawings that were producer Albin Grau's original renderings of Nosferatu.<br />The DVD packaging -- cardboard case with plastic snap -- may be cheap, but it contains within one of filmdom's finest moments, and provides far more than just 81 minutes of enjoyment.  Highly, highly recommended.

0064409422|5.0|Death, that state of consciousness which seems to be most feared by men, often plays an important role in fantasy writing, albeit under various guises, as is evidenced by C. S. Lewis. In this book, Lewis presents the possibility and probability that Death may be Life, that Death may be Reality, that Death may be ALL.<BR>   In this tale, Lewis takes the very stuff of which Death is made and, by going beyond its form, on into its depths, sets it aright with all that is so that It, likewise, can be all that It is to all. In so doing, he allows each character to experience the wonders of Death and rebirth on his own level, according to his personal concepts, to his personal feelings, to his personal needs.<BR>   As viewed through Lewis's pen, Death is an &quot;adventure&quot; to which Lucy is attracted because of its depth, of its mystery, of its light, qualities which whet her curiosity.<BR>   Death is &quot;social justice,&quot; the law of the land, which requires punishment for transgressions perpetrated against authority, that law which is based upon &quot;an eye for an eye, a tooth for a tooth.&quot; This leads to an understanding of the Law of Karma, which states that each person is responsible for the results of his actions and must suffer the consequences.<BR>   Death is &quot;food for pride&quot; in the heart of the White Witch, whose very life is dependent upon the obedience of her subjects who must not question her commands.<BR>   Death is &quot;self-sacrifice&quot; in the redemption of Edmund by Aslan, who understands well the cosmic law of Cause and Effect and who, more than all, knows of Death's illusion.<BR>   Death is &quot;liberation&quot; for the citizens of Narnia, liberation from their instinctive fears which bind them to serve the White Witch, who provides for their needs while keeping them dependent upon her and thus ignorant of her true identity.<BR>   Death is &quot;cooperation&quot; against the forces of evil, once having realized the strength of group consciousness.<BR>   Death is &quot;the present moment&quot; in blessed forgetfulness of the past.<BR>   Death is &quot;rebirth,&quot; constant transformation.<BR>   In writing this tale, Lewis has given us another look at the meaning of stability versus change, of good versus evil, and of their relativity, all the while spawning the following equation in the mind of many: Reality = Death &amp; Rebirth.

B000002H97|2.0|People who are not familiar with Metallica may really like this record. But those who have listened to Metallica since 'Kill Em All' may very well find themselves disappointed. Their 2nd record 'Ride the Lightning' was a timeless masterpiece to be enjoyed again and again. This 5th record is simply tragic. Gone is the musical intensity and the killer vocals seen on earlier records. I am not so uptight that I'll deny that this record is a decent spare hour passer, but to call this one of Metallica's best efforts (to put it in civil language) is absurd. IT SAYS SOMETHING WHEN THE PEOPLE WHO LIKE THE ALBUM ARE NOT MADE UP OF PEOPLE WHO ALWAYS LIKED THE GROUP, AND THE PEOPLE WHO ALWAYS LIKED THE GROUP ARE TRULY LET DOWN! I find it interesting that people try to excuse sell out records by saying that the group has matured. This is absurd. A compromise of  what they were good at for the sake of higher financial gain is the definition of selling out. William Shakespeare started out with mediocre plays like &quot;Titus Andronicus.&quot; When his writing matured, he gave us the frighteningly intense masterpieces of &quot;Julius Caesar,&quot; &quot;Macbeth,&quot; &quot;Hamlet,&quot; and &quot;King Lear.&quot; Charles Dickens' early &quot;Old Curiosity Shop&quot; has some grand elements like the really likable villain Daniel Quilp and the eccentric but benevolent Dick Swiveller. But Dickens' writing matured to offer us the frighteningly intense &quot;Our Mutual Friend.&quot; Going back to heavy metal, King Diamond started out with the o.k. &quot;Melissa.&quot; But his writing got more frightening, and his musical efforts got more intense, and he started using more musical resources. Just listen to his later efforts &quot;Them,&quot; &quot;Conspiracy,&quot; &quot;Abigail,&quot; and &quot;In the Shadows.&quot; The bottom line is don't confuse two things that don't go together. Maturing is maturing and selling out is selling out. I don't deny that this record has a sound that mayappeal to some, but if like me, you are a fan of older Metallica like &quot;Kill Em All&quot; and &quot;Ride the Lightning&quot; you may very well be disappointed. SUGGESTION: If you can, borrow this record from someone; give it a listen; then decide if you would like to buy it.

B0000024ZT|5.0|One of the greatest debut albums of all-time. Not only did &quot;Greetings From Asbury Park&quot; put unfashionable New Jersey back on the map, it also launched one of the longest and most important careers in rock's history. The 23 year-old Springsteen displayed a remarkable brand of lyrical verbosity not heard since the heady hey day of Bob Dylan circa &quot;Blonde on Blonde&quot;. Of course, the imminent Dylan comparsions were unavoidable, but the ambitious young star refused to let the hype machine eat him up. While much has been made of &quot;Greetings'&quot; poor production, nothing could possibly detract from the quality of Springsteen's songwriting. Nearly 30 years after their release, songs such as &quot;For You&quot;, &quot;Spirit in the Night&quot; and &quot;It's Hard to be a Saint in the City&quot; still rank among the upper echelon of Springsteen's work. Lyrically, Bruce would never quite approach the lofty heights he reached on &quot;Greetings&quot; and its magnificient follow-up &quot;The Wild, the Innocent and the E Street Shuffle&quot;. Colorful imagery practically jumps off the grooves on every track. From the wild verbal assault of &quot;Blinded By the Light&quot; to the poetically violent gunfight of &quot;Lost in the Flood&quot;, Bruce never lets down his guard. Zany characters with eccentric names like Crazy Janey and Mission Man pop up all over the place. The hastily assembled band, loose and ready to roll, so perfectly suits the rapid-fire vocal delivery of the raspy-voiced Springsteen. The whole experience is sheer unadultrated joy. Ironically, being the adventurous piece of work that it was, &quot;Greetings&quot; proved to be an abysmal financial flop. Practically no one outside of Philadelphia, New York or New Jersey was even aware of Springsteen. Within a few years that would all change. While Bruce would eventually become an international superstar, I personally believe that he would never again display the brilliant artistry of his first three albums (&quot;Greetings&quot;, &quot; The Wild, the Innocent&quot; and &quot;Born to Run&quot;). Bruce's current work lacks that urgent sense of abandon which made &quot;Greetings&quot; so darn enjoyable. In fact, fans only familiar with his post 1980 output may be shocked to realize that, once upon a time, listening to Bruce Springsteen was actually fun! &quot;Greetings From Asbury Park, N.J.&quot; is more than just fun, however, it's the embodiment of the spirit of rock-n-roll. Great album. Highly recommended.
B00005OWIU|5.0|My 10 year old daughter is a HUGH Harry fan and when the CD came out, I immediately grabbed it!  Brought it home, popped it in and was transfixed!  My daughter loves the orchestration and dances around the room.  If you want to give your kids an &quot;introduction&quot; to classical....this just may be the one to start!
B000002UAU|5.0|The Beatles' best album? Probably not. That honor is reserved for &quot;Revolver&quot; or &quot;Rubber Soul&quot;. Most eclectic? Nope, that would be the &quot;White Album&quot;. Most elaborately produced? Try &quot;Abbey Road&quot;. Most famous record? Most influential? Bingo! That's &quot;Sgt. Pepper&quot;. Not only the most influential entry in the Beatles' catalog, but also the most far-reaching and well known recording of the entire rock-era.<br />Volumes have been written about the phenomenom of &quot;Sgt. Pepper&quot; and the social impact it bestowed upon its release in June 1967. The psychedelic sound collages of &quot;Being for the Benefit of Mr. Kite&quot; and &quot;A Day in the Life&quot; served not only as a soundtrack for the Summer of Love, but also influenced an entire generation of &quot;serious&quot; rock musicians. For better, or in many cases, for worse, rock was forever changed by &quot;Sgt. Pepper&quot;. Superb musicianship and production became all the rage. Lyrics, which were actually printed on &quot;Pepper's&quot; jacket, were suddenly taken seriously. Critics took note and the bar was raised as countless artists attempted to create their own &quot;Sgt. Pepper&quot; -style masterpieces. Of course, many of these imitations were downright laughable, but nevertheless, a new genre known as &quot;progressive&quot; rock was born in the aftermath of &quot;Sgt. Pepper&quot;.<br />Ironically, when discussing &quot;Pepper&quot;, the album's great songs almost get lost in the shuffle. The title song, &quot;Lucy in the Sky with Diamonds&quot;, &quot;With a Little Help From My Friends&quot; and &quot;A Day in the Life&quot; are permanently ingrained in the heads of rock fans everywhere. However, for me, lesser-known jewels such as &quot;Fixing a Hole&quot; and &quot;Lovely Rita&quot; are more enjoyable. They're lighter and more fun to listen to than their better know counterparts. The charging herd of animals which blasts through the tailend of &quot;Good Morning, Good Morning&quot; is one of the most humorous moments in Beatledom. The perfect seque of a chicken clucking into the opening notes of &quot;Sgt. Pepper (Reprise)&quot; is a touch of genius. Ditto the gibberish tagged on the end of the album which, on vinyl, went on eternally. For me, these are the special touches which make &quot;Sgt.Pepper&quot; a unique listening experience. Overall, &quot;Pepper&quot; is truly a joyous musical journey --one which, like many Beatle records, occurred at the right time and the right place. It's almost as if the Beatles could read the collective mind of the world, giving people exactly what they needed, while uniting millions in the process. Boy, could the world use the Beatles now.

Airbag: A trippy drum loop plus uplifting guitars makes for a sonic rush that flies through the ears.<BR>2. Paranoid Android: A masterpiece, in 3 parts that sound like their own songs. The speed changes constantly from normal to quick to slow and back around.<BR>3. Subterranean Homesick Alien (correct spelling?): Marshy guitars meet oddball lyrics.<BR>4. Exit Music (for a film): An powerful tear rendering song that goes from slow to the top of Thom's anguished voice.<BR>5. Let Down: Happy, uplifting, though a tad repetitive.<BR>6. Karma Police: Piano ridden with great lyrics.<BR>7. Fitter Happier: Chilling Vocal (If thats what you could call it) piece that makes a person think hard at what is being said.<BR>8. Electioneering: The albums rocker, with loud guitars and common drum beat.  <BR>9. Climbing the Walls: Eeerie vocals, eerie lyrics, and eerie music makes for an almost chilling experience.<BR>10. No Surprises: Beautifully carveed poppy music.<BR>11. Lucky: Anguished sound makes for a head trip.<BR>12. The Tourist: An awesome closing to the album leaves on a happy note and a valuable message of slowing down.<br />I think that OK Computer may be one of the best albums of the nineties since it fits the mood and atmosphere of the decade, and shows Radiohead's impact on music.
B00005K9LK|4.0|First, I should point out that my rating is an average of both the music and the sound quality:<br />First, the music--with the sole exception of &quot;Pain and Pleasure&quot;--simply flat out rocks. I don't need to say any more than that. If you're new to Priest, this definitely serves as an excellent starter. It rocks! 5 stars for the music.<br />BUT, the sound quality is a different story altogether. To all of you audiophiles out there, I'm giving you the warning right now: NOISE REDUCTION WAS USED!! I knew immediately upon seeing Jon Astley's name for the remastering credit that something wasn't going to sound right... I'm sorry to say I was right. For those of you who don't know, Jon Astley is a mastering engineer that has an evil and pathetic habit of employing noise reduction &quot;technologies&quot; to practically every project he gets his hands on. On some songs, luckily, you can barely tell he used it. However, if you listen through headphones, the use of noise reduction is all too obvious in both the intro vocals to &quot;(Take These) Chains&quot; (it sounds like it has some sort of metallic squeaking in the background) and in the first four or so bars of &quot;You've Got Another Thing Comin'&quot;, particularly noticeable on the high-hat in the drums. And, just to be sure that this wasn't the way it was recorded, I compared the version with a vinyl copy my friend has. Nope--it doesn't sound like that there. This a terribly poor &quot;remastering,&quot; and I *VERY* highly doubt this reissue was even taken from the original master tapes. Where is a REAL mastering engineer like Vic Anesini, Bernie Grundman, or Steve Hoffman when you need him? I simply can't believe Sony would do such a blasphemous thing to the almighty Priest catalog. 3 stars for the sound quality. <br />So, there you go: 5 stars for the music + 3 stars sound quality yields a four star average.
B0000508U6|5.0|In the modern barrage of wannabe Pearl Jam bands and screaching Teen Princesses, Coldplay manages to offer something different, but still something that people more adapted to the mainstream radio stations can enjoy.  It sounds to me like Coldplay has mixed the quirky britishness and song structure of Radiohead and the lushness and lyrics of Duncan Sheik or Jeff Buckley to make an enjoyable sophisticated album.

6305878323|5.0|I was nine years old when Walt Disney produced the first movie I remember being a \\"must see\\": Mary Poppins.  After seeing it numerous times as a child, I bought the new DVD - thought I might enjoy seeing it again and sharing it with my nieces and nephews.<br />Mary Poppins retains the same magic and wonder that I remember experiencing as a child. She still remains this enigma - who was she really?  Where did she come from?  What was really going on between her and Bert? The movie answers none of these questions - it just lets them float in the air like it's magical heroine. And that's part of its charm.  The film seems to live by Mary's maxim: \\"I never explain anything\\".<br />Technically - the film holds up as well, even in this age of digital everything.  I was amazed to learn (in the \\"Making of\\" documentary that's included on the CD) that the film was shot entirely on the Disney soundstages in Burbank.  They never went on location; they never even went outside.  London is \\"painted in\\" in a series of beautiful matte glass paintings.  (If I remember correctly, even today, it is the largest number of glass background paintings ever used in a film.)<br />Julie Andrews, of course, is \\"practically perfect in every way\\" as Mary - a much more idiosyncratic character than the governess she famously played in \\"Sound of Music\\" a year later.  And that clear soprano voice - never showy, always in character - just lifts the film.  Dick Van Dyke is wonderful as Bert - though accents are clearly not his strong suit.  But as a comic, a mime, a singer and a dancer he is charming as the Jack-of-all-trades friend of Mary.<br />The DVD looks great.  It's letterboxed - but it wasn't shot in wide screen format - so you don't loose much on your TV screen.  The colors are snappy and true.  There is a new \\"Making of\\" feature, produced especially for the DVD hosted by Dick Van Dyke and featuring interviews with Julie, and some of the other technical team that are still around.  There is some great home movie footage of the chimney sweep dancers rehearsing \\"Step in Time\\" outside in the California heat stripped down to their skivvies.<br />The one thing on the DVD I do NOT appreciated is a long series of promos for other Disney video releases that you can't cancel out of easily and skip to the film. I think it's rather shameless forcing kids to sit through those commercials to see their favorite movie.<br />All in all - a beautiful presentation of a classic film that adults and children can enjoy together.is some great home movie footage of the chimney sweep dancers rehearsing \\"Step in Time\\" outside in the California heat stripped down to their skivvies.  <br />The one thing on the DVD I do NOT appreciated is a long series of promos for other Disney video releases that you can't cancel out of easily and skip to the film. B000007MVL|4.0|Kate's second album is mellower than most of her work.  Most of it is Kate's still-girlish vocals and her piano. She sees God as tempering the beast from red to blue, and guiding her towards her symphony, for which she is needed.<br />&quot;Oh England, My Lionheart&quot; is a wonderful love song to the country of Shakespeare, Peter Pan, London Bridge, a country whose arms warmly embraces her and that she never wants to leave, even when she's ready to shuffle off that coil.  For her, this is an England after the devastating effects of the Second World War, where clovers grow where air-raid shelters used to be.<br />&quot;In The Warm Room&quot; is an erotically beautiful song sensually sung from Kate's lips.  &quot;You'll fall into her like a pillow/Her thighs are soft as marshmallows/Say hello, to the soft musk of her hollows&quot;  Now that's just beautiful writing with wonderful similes.<br />The slightly bouncy &quot;Coffee Homeground&quot; with a witty chorus of arsenic in the tea, (a nod to Arsenic And Old Lace surely), and mentions of cyanide in chocolate, belladonna in coffee, depicts all the ways the lonely serial killer disposes of whoever comes to visit her. 0156013983|5.0|Le Petit Prince, published more than half a century ago, endures into the twenty-first century as a beautifully written children's novel and a powerful philosophic work that speaks volumes about love and friendship.  Written by Antoine de Saint-Exupery during World War II, Le Petit Prince was published as a children's story, but soon became recognized the world over as a profound introspective statement.  By using the novel as a type of allegory, Saint-Exupery was able to write a commentary on life as he had lived it.  The novel takes readers on a fantastic journey through the universe that, by the end, will have even the most hardened soul in tears.<br /> The novel, although simply written, is not simple in style or in taste.  Saint-Exupery uses powerful metaphors, similes, and analogies to address the very abstract themes of love and friendship.  By personifying many of the personality traits that make up a true friend, Saint-Exupery makes these complicated issues so simple that even a child could understand.  This is, of course, what Saint-Exupery had in mind all along.<br /> I loved Le Petit Prince and have read many of my favorites parts to members of my family and just about anyone else who will listen.  That is the magic of this novel.  Beautifully written and illustrated, it will have you coming back to relive the adventures of the little prince time and time again.  Through the eyes of Antoine de Saint-Exupery, this often-troubling world becomes a universe filled with the possibilities of true friendship and lasting love.

Even the soundtrack is copied from other shows, with the exception of \\"Journey of Man\\", which is a great song, but is much better (and is complete) on the audio CD.<br />There are a couple of pros, though. B00000IL1K|5.0|What a stunningly, beautiful voice this talented singer has!  I have played this CD over and over again in the weeks since I bought it and probably will wear the CD out by Christmas - and replace immediately...<br />Sarah switches between a wide range of singing styles and in my view does so with grace and flair.  I disagree entirely with some comments I have read that refer to her 'sameness of tone' or 'small voice'.  She isn't an opera singer by profession, as far as I am aware, but by goodness she can hold a tune - I know 'cos I love opera and can spot the difference.  And yes, it must be said that the CD does have an opera feel about it.  But don't let that put you off, because Sarah puts heart and soul into some wonderful, hauntingly beautiful songs, which you will grow to love, regardless of an opera label.<br />You know that song from Titanic?  I hated it - fed up with hearing it... but Sarah's version of this is just breathtaking in my opinion.  She delivers this song with much more heart and passion, yet at the same time, purity and simplicity of voice, than I think Celine Dion did.  Anyway, can't get the damn song out of my head now... but thanks Sarah - absolutely wonderful!!<br />Buy this or you are mad!!!!

B000002KFJ|5.0|There are over sixty reviews of this album posted here as I write this. Why put up another? Because I love this disc!<br />This (released in 1975 and the sixth album from Black Sabbath) is a classic recording that simultaneously defines the heavy metal genre and warps that genre with progressive rock flourishes and baroque pseudo-classicism. This may sound pretentious but, in conjunction with the grinding guitar riffs that Tony Iommi all but trademarked and the haunted wail that is Ozzy's voice, the sound captured here is a shining example of the best that hard rock/heavy metal can be.<br />The album opens with a brief moment of background studio noise, a frightening squawk as if from some hellish bird of prey, and then a short countdown before \\"Hole in the Sky\\" erupts from your speakers with a barrage of sound and cryptic lyrics (\\"Hole in the sky, take me to heaven. Window inside, through it I'll fly!\\") that will leave your gray matter whirling. Track number two, \\"Don't Start (Too Late)\\", is an instrumental interlude comprised mainly of Tony Iommi's classical style guitar noodlings that will allow you to just catch your breath before the epic \\"Symptom of the Universe\\" takes that breath right back from you with its pounding introduction and lyrics of cosmic love(\\"All I have to give you is a love that never dies. The symptom of the universe is written in your eyes.\\"). Themes of insanity (\\"Megalomania\\") and religion (\\"The Thrill of it All\\") echo through the rest of the album and the total effect is unforgettable and vintage Sabbath.<br />This is an album that should satisfy the simplest headbanger and the more discerning fan of heavy music. In short, this is Black Sabbath at their best.

B000002HK4|4.0|A Change of Seasons is noteworthy for a number of reasons: (1) it re-unites Dream Theater with producer David Prater, who made their second album (Images and Words) such a pleasure to listen to; it's the first album featuring new keyboard player Derek Sherinian; and its selection of music is second to none.<br />This, DT's fourth studio album (1995), isn't quite as heavy as the previous release -- the bone-crushingly excessive Awake -- and that's a real blessing. Their talent shows through even more vividly because there are patches of intricate melody amidst the bombast that give one's mind a place to rest.<br />This album divides itself neatly into two halves: the 23-minute title track (sprinkled liberally with Carpe Diem -- seize the day -- philosophies)...and the live second half that's a feast for classic rock fans. DT covers Elton John's &quot;Funeral For a Friend,&quot; Deep Purple's &quot;Perfect Strangers,&quot; three from Led Zep (&quot;The Rover,&quot; &quot;Achilles Last Stand&quot; and &quot;The Song Remains the Same&quot;) and what DT calls &quot;The Big Medley,&quot; which is one cool song after another -- from Pink Floyd's &quot;In the Flesh&quot; to Queen's &quot;Bohemian Rhapsody&quot; to Genesis' &quot;Turn it On Again.&quot;<br />&quot;A Change of Seasons,&quot; the epic-length title track, is well-played, and shows more creative restraint than you'll find on Awake. I like it a lot.<br />...but I like the live cover songs even more. <br />One of the biggest challenges any band faces when doing covers is getting the sounds right, especially the guitar tones. Tackling the right notes and getting all the arrangements to sound similar to the original band is tough enough. But getting the right sounds out of the guitars and keyboards can be a real challenge.<br />Yet, I'll be darned if DT doesn't pull it off with their trademark virtuosity. Even guitarist John Petrucci's solo mirroring Brian May's in &quot;Bohemian Rhapsody&quot; is almost note-for-note perfect.<br />You can tell DT was having a great time paying tribute to some of their favorite bands in the live portion of this CD. And their joy is contagious.<br />While A Change of Seasons will never be considered DT's best work, it's still one heck of a fun CD. I highly recommend it.
B00005OM4N|2.0|For me, this is a big disappointment.  I have both previous Britney albums, and have enjoyed them immensely, especially her debut album.  But this, what is supposed to be a musical departure, doesnt sound that different and certainly doesnt contain a lot of the melodies that attracted me to Britney in the first place.<BR>'Slave' is interesting, and yes, is a more mature style for her.  My favourite track on the album is 'Boys' but hey, there is such a similarity between this and Prince's 'Get Off'.<BR>A disappointing album, but I am not writing her off yet.<BR>One for the fans I think...
B000002JPA|5.0|This is my second favorite Dream Theater album after When Dream and Day Unite, their debut release.<br />On this release -- Images and Words -- the melodies are flawless, the music is uplifting, the musicianship is unbelievable and the vocals (supplied by new vocalist James LaBrie) are soaring but not irritating as they are on subsequent releases. (He tends to overuse a melodramatic breathy-ness, but at least he's hitting the notes he's reaching for on this album!)<br />I'm not surprised this album catapulted DT into the stratosphere. Every song is brilliant. The guitar tracks are more out front than on their debut (but not so far out front that they've become bone-crushing and lacking in melody) and the production is superb. The balance is perfect between heavy and delicate, dark and light. Kevin Moore's keyboard work is nothing short of amazing. Check out the gentle intro to &quot;Wait For Sleep.&quot;<br />&quot;Pull Me Under,&quot; the opening track, was a big hit at the time of the album's release (1992). But, for me, the stand-out tracks are &quot;Another Day,&quot; &quot;Take the Time&quot; and &quot;Metropolis - Part I.&quot;<br />I've been on a Dream Theater binge lately (spurred by the release of their new triple-CD Live Scenes From New York, as well as listening to DT drummer Mike Portnoy's side project TransAtlantic). I've been listening to their entire catalog in order of release. Images and Words, a CD I haven't heard in years, is playing at the moment...and I'm realizing anew just how incredible it is.<br />Images and Words is brimming over with energy and stellar performances from all five members of the band. What a powerful album.<br />If you're fan of progressive rock -- or what's become known as &quot;progressive metal&quot; -- you need to have a copy of Images and Words. It's the perfect balance between art and rock.

This is her R&amp;B / Soul moment (with a mix of electronica / pop)<br />The same applies here, though in my opinion (and i am a HUGE fan of hers), this album contains some of her stongest, but also weakest moments.<br />Lets get the weak tracks out of the way first: 'Survival', 'I'd rather be your lover',the single 'Human nature', and the pleasant song, 'Dont stop'.<br />The remaining tracks are outstanding.<BR>The beautiful 'Take a bow', the haunting 'Love tried to welcome me' and moving and beautiful 'Inside of me'.<BR>As for the more upbeat moments, the fascinating 'Sanctuary', quoting the poems of Walt Whitman, and the Bjork penned title track.<br />Despite its weaker moments, this is still a great album.<BR>Perhaps get Ray of Light / Music and Erotica first if you havent already, but dont by-pass this.
B000002JKA|3.0|The musicianship on Awake is extraordinary. No doubt about it. <br />John Petrucci is one of today's most accomplished and technically brilliant guitarists. And drummer Mike Portnoy is a monster, rivaled only by the likes of Neal Peart. Bassist John Myung is nothing short of astounding. And Kevin Moore is his usual melodic and surprising self (unfortunately, this was his last album with the band).<br />So why only three stars? Two hard-to-ignore reasons:<br />1. James LaBrie's vocals are among the most irritating I've ever heard. His I-know-there's-a-note-out-there-somewhere screams grate on my nerves in an unbelievable way. On this album -- DT's third studio release -- he alternates between a menacing growl, an over-the-top bellow and his trademark breathy-ness. And does so with the finesse of a wrecking ball.<br />2. The production is so in-your-face that it's almost too heavy for my taste. To me, above a certain decibel level, guitars lose their ability to uplift, stir, amaze and captivate and, instead, simply settle for crushing bones and scaring small children. The balance between light and dark, between heavy and delicate, so artfully struck on Images and Words, has been obliterated on Awake. This album is heavy, heavy, heavy.<br />And LaBrie is screaming, screaming, screaming.<br />All writers need a good editor. And all bands need a good producer, one who won't lead them over the top -- and off a cliff. On Awake, I think the line was crossed.<br />The albums begins with a bang -- Mike Portnoy's drum roll -- on &quot;6:00.&quot; The heavy tone and brisk pace are established with this track...and both don't let up until the very last track (&quot;Space Dye Vest&quot;).<br />&quot;Caught in a Web,&quot; the second track, is playing on my office CD player now. And LaBrie is screaming again. Shouting at the top of his lungs, in fact. It's God-awful.<br />The following track -- &quot;Innocence Faded&quot; -- is a welcome breath of fresh air. It's melodic and uplifting, showing signs of much-needed creative restraint. Great chorus. Nice background vocals. All in all, a pleasant respite from the bombasity of the rest of the album. (LaBrie displays both top-of-his-lungs shouting and that hideous breathy singing on this track. Try to ignore him.)<br />&quot;Erotomania&quot; picks up where &quot;Ytse Jam&quot; (from When Dream and Day Unite) left off. It's a clever and stirring instrumental track that buries the keyboards and cranks up the guitars. It's fantastic playing, and LaBrie is nowhere to be found. So this track gets two thumbs up from Yours Truly.<br />&quot;Voices&quot; begins with some moody, almost spooky bass, keyboard and guitar sounds, puncuated by Portnoy's heavy-footed drumming. Cool track.<br />&quot;The Silent Man&quot; is a slow, acoustic guitar track with lots of LaBrie to be heard. I'll bet you can guess what I think of it.<br />&quot;The Mirror&quot; (track seven) is another heavy, heavy, heavy track with lots of double bass work from Portnoy to further add to the feeling that my head is being crushed when I listen to it. Especially with headphones on.<br />The rest of the album pretty much follows suit, with a guitar sound that's distorted to the point of atonal. Where's the melody?<br />Despite the album's weaknesses (and there are many), it still stands as one of the best examples of music skillfully played you'll find anywhere.<br />If you're new to Dream Theater, don't start with Awake. Start with Images and Words, When Dream and Day Unite or Scenes From a Memory. Awake is liable to scare the crap out of you.
B000002N3J|5.0|Madonna put this compilation together, to remind people that she is a talented artist, and that she is not all about 'controversy'.<br />This is not a greatest hits (get'The Immaculate Collection' and 'GHV2') but complements them beautifully. <BR>It is a collection of her greatest ballads, the majority of which were singles (9), but it includes greats such as the title track, lifted off the 'I'm Breathless' album, 'Forbidden Love' taken from 'Bedtime Stories', and 3 brand new tracks, 'You'll See', 'One More Chance' and 'I Want You' with Massive Attack (in 2 different versions).<BR>9 of these tracks you cant get on any other Madonna compilation.<br />A worthwhile additon to your music collection.
B000002HPT|4.0|Falling Into Infinity is a different sound for DT. Especially for vocalist James LaBrie.<br />It's hard to say what's not the same about this album. But it's noticeably different from its predecessors. Maybe it's the groove this album seems to have, a more bottom-heavy undercurrent (like on &quot;New Millennium,&quot; &quot;You Not Me&quot; or &quot;Peruvian Skies&quot;) that drives it along. Maybe producer Kevin Shirley wanted more of a total band effort than a guitar onslaught. So he buried the drums and toned back the guitars, and kept the overall pace a little on the sluggish side.<br />I don't know what it is. But it's a great change of pace. And one, according to some other reviews, that wasn't terribly well received among DT fans.<br />It runs the gamut, though. There's even a Flamenco-tinged track called &quot;Hollow Years&quot; that sounds like something you'd hear on an easy-listening station. Or on a dance floor at a wedding somewhere. It's almost a pop song, which is very strange for DT. But, to me, it works.<br />&quot;Burning My Soul,&quot; the fifth track, begins with a grinding bass line and a slowly building keyboard, guitar and drum montage (love that double bass action from Portnoy!). But then LaBrie joins in, screaming as usual, and the track goes into the dumpster.<br />&quot;Hell's Kitchen,&quot; track #6, opens with an atmospheric, moody bass, keyboard and guitar pastiche that slowly builds, but never reaches its full potential -- even though it has 12 minutes in which to do it.<br />I like the next track -- &quot;Lines in the Sand&quot; -- largely because of keyboardist Derek Sherinian's intro. Sherinian sets the stage for a more aggressive, syncopated assault that's one of the highlights of the album for me.<br />&quot;Take Away My Pain&quot; (track # 8) seems like a Genesis song, circa their pop years with Phil Collins at the helm. I think it's the way the guitar sounds.<br />&quot;Just Let Me Breathe&quot; (track 9) is another mid-paced tune that's reminiscent of recent Rush, in my opinion. Maybe it's the bass line.<br />&quot;Anna Lee&quot; is a slow, love-songish LaBrie showcase that begins with a piano that sounds like '70s era Elton John to me. Nice background vocals throughought. Pleasant, by not terribly inspiring.<br />The last track (&quot;Trial of Tears&quot;) is -- at 13:07 -- the longest on the album. Divided into three parts, it has a bit of Rush in it (circa &quot;Xanadu&quot;). And a raspy bass line that reminds me of something Tony Levin would create. In fact, this sounds a little like Liquid Tension Experiment, Portnoy's side project, the first album of which appeared a year after this DT album.<br />Overall, this is certainly not one of DT's best albums. Yet, I gave it four stars just of the first few tracks that I like a lot -- and, more importantly, because of the balls it must have taken to create something a bit riskier than another Awake or A Change of Seasons. It shows these guys are willing to try new things.<br />And isn't that what progressive rock is all about?

B0000025ZF|3.0|That song on this album should be considered prophetic and ominous in todays world since September 11th...
B000000W6F|5.0|This is a beautiful and unique hard rock album. It's not perfect from start to finish (very few albums are), but its strengths are SO strong, its good songs (which fill about 80% of the disc) so worth hearing, that it easily earns five stars from me. Billy Corgan's guitar sounds are just gorgeous, shimmering and crying. Jimmy Chamberlin shapes each song by using the full dynamic and tonal range of the drumset, something most rock drummers haven't even attempted to do since the sixties. This approach is obvious on &quot;Window Pane,&quot; but check out &quot;Suffer&quot; and &quot;Snail&quot; especially to hear how Jimmy can lead the band around a corner with a sudden rise or dip in intensity. (The lack of this sort of drumming on _Mellon Collie_ is one of that album's real drawbacks. Most of the drum tracks sound like loops, and it makes the songs feel monotonous.) But the greatest thing about this record to me is how so many of the songs undergo a transformation, and end up a different song than they began. This is very rare indeed in any era of rock music. Orchestral symphonies usually do this, on a huge scale. The jazz compositions of Kenny Wheeler, Gerry Hemingway, and Dave Douglas often do this, and improvised jazz solos do it sometimes. But rock tends to be based on recurrence and somewhat circular forms -- even the progressive bands of the 70s usually finished a song by restating the original theme in the original way. The Pumpkins, by consistently getting from point A to point B (in under 5 minutes), have created what will probably remain a masterpiece, not just of the 1990s, but of all rock &amp; roll.
B00005NTJM|4.0|you probably have to really be a fan of Jethro Tull to fully appreciate this album. First, it reveals the formative qualities of the band, before they became more established in their ways of working and playing together. Second, it does not feature Martin Barre, because the guitarist on this first album is Mick Abrams. But, if you can tolerate the unusual, you are in for a treat! One is the flute lead in Serenade for a Cuckoo, in which Ian Anderson establishes his credentials as a jazz/rock flutist. In addition is the tune Cat's Squirrel, which I alway enjoyed comparing to the tune of the same name by Eric Clapton and Cream, not so much as to determine which one is better, but to enjoy the interpretation developed in each. The rest of the songs might be perceived to be uneven, but well worth the exploration. I've enjoyed digging out this album over the past 30 years, and it has that kind of staying power over time.
B00005OM4N|5.0|The highly antcipated 3rd album &quot;Britney&quot; from the infamous Britney Spears, is definitley this talented singers best as of yet! The album is a more mature, harder pop, with twists of R&amp;B, Rock, and Funk/Dance. The first single and track, &quot;I'm A Slave 4 U&quot;, produced by the funkalicious Neptunes, mixes R&amp;B beats with smoothe vocals to make it an awesome first single, which shows off Britneys new musical direction! Next theres &quot;Overprotected&quot;, which is definitley one of the best on the album. Its a hard pop beat produced by Max Martin (did most of 'Baby...' and 'Oops...' albums), as well as &quot;Cinderella&quot;, both written by Britney herself! Next theres the sole ballad on the album, &quot;I'm Not A Girl...&quot;, penned by Dido, which is by far her best yet. Then theres R&amp;B influenced songs such as &quot;Boys&quot;, produced by the Neptunes as well, a rocker song &quot;Lonely&quot;, produced by Rodney Jerkins as well as &quot;Let Me Be&quot;, which are both written by Britney too, and of course sound great as well. Theres &quot;Thats Where You Take Me&quot;, a classic techno-ballad written by Britney,  and &quot;Bombastic Love&quot; which are Pop/Dance influenced as well, with great lyrics and beats! Brit did an awesome cover of the Joan Jett classic &quot;I Love Rock N Roll&quot;, another produced by Rodney Jerkins, which is also more R&amp;B, which actually lives up to the original. A pop-disco song &quot;Anticipating&quot;, written by Britney as well, is a great song to sing to and dance as well. Finally theres &quot;What It's Like To Be Me&quot;, which was produced by Britney's boyfriend Justin Timberlake from *N'SYNC, and Wade Robson, their choreographer. The song is like a rock opera, with Justins vocals in the background. 0156421178|5.0|This is one of the most important books of the 20th Century.  Orwell went to Spain as somewhat of a vaguely committed leftist; when he returned, he had truly found not only himself but the course of the remainder of the century.  Orwell discovers that things rarely exist in black and white but in a million shades of gray; there rarely is a &quot;good side&quot; in any contest. Tyranny is tyranny whether it wears the swastika or the hammer and sickle.  Another aspect of this book, for people who only know Orwell through Animal Farm and 1984, is his bravery.  He was right in the thick of everything and lived to write one of the truest, most searing documents of the last 100 years.  As a chronicle of war before WWII, I think it ranks with Graves's Goodbye to All That.  In both books, the writer plummets to the depths of human experience and fear and surfaces with enlightenment.
B000003S0R|5.0|Lyrically Eno plays little narrative games,&quot;...and the opium farmers sell dreams to obscure fraternities...down in the orchard monkeys and uncles p-laying their games like it seems they always have done....China my China I wandered around for years and you're still here&quot;(China my China).<br />Musically the sounds are a mix of the familiar Manzanera guitar and Mackay sax(his two old Roxy Music chums)but also unfamiliar Eno synthesizers which make some very appealing noise and various other unfamiliar aural delights from all manner of unidentifiable sources.<br />There are so many lyric devices and different sounds that this album feels like a catalogue or manual. Perhaps the Eno equivalent of the Little Red Book.<br />The beautiful synthesizer phrasings on the closing number Taking Tiger Mountain could easily fit on Another Green World.<br />Other songs are pure pop heaven though, when Eno sings &quot;Looking for a certain ratio-o-o-o&quot; you can hear that he has learned something from Bryan Ferry. A vocal style Talking Heads' David Byrne will also use.<br />Fat Lady of Limbourg is perhaps the star of the show but not by much as every song is a winning combination of odd verse and even odder backing noises. Though its experimental its also fun and listenable as any pop record if not more so. There is plenty here to challenge the playful mind that always is looking for something new, Enos sound terrains are always intriguing, and also there is humor, especially in the words, and a great sense of wandering into the unknown because logical thinking and music making patterns have been left behind. Although familiar things keep popping up, like references to Japan or China, and cold war spy apparatus like microcameras and spectrographs, they are merely there to add drama and a touch of reality c.1974, but only a touch. Tiger Mountain is not to be located on a map.
B00005O5CM|4.0|Poor Elle... her boyfriend has just dumped her, forcing her to relinguish her glamorous Los Angeles lifestyle to pursue a career in law at Harvard Law School. No one likes her; she feels despondent and alone... what's a girl to do? Why, get a manicure, of course! <br />In &quot;Legally Blonde,&quot; one might expect voracious amounts of high-pitched voices, pouting, and out-of-nowhere remarks and comments that have become the constituent image for blondes everywhere. The movie includes all of these things, no doubt, but somehow manages to cast them in a witty and extremely humorous light, while also possessing a heart and soul that are easy to relate to. It's a priceless comedic gem, and gave me every reason to fall into its spell. <br />In a performance that is easily likeable and irresistibly charming, Reese Witherspoon plays Elle Woods, who hopes to be accepted to Harvard Law School to prove to her ex-boyfriend that she's not too stupid to be a lawyer's wife. With a 4.0 grade average, a fashion major from CULA, and a video essay featuring herself and others in bikinis (a tactic made funnier by the fact that she doesn't realize the effect she will have on the all-male board at Harvard), she is accepted, and arrives intent on winning back her man. <br />Of course, things are not all parties and homecomings, and she soon discovers that no one really cares to be around her. Former prospective fianc Warner is now engaged to the snotty Vivian Kensington, leaving Elle's plans in the cold. With no one to turn to except for Paulette, a manicurist with low self esteem, Elle decides to take life into her own hands, and quickly learns the tricks of the trade at Harvard. <br />This is where the movie takes on a personality much like its main character. By setting out to prove her worth as a law student, Elle shows a determination full of energy and real drive. By doing so, she becomes more than just the stereotypical blonde bombshell everyone sees her as, and in allowing her character to expand, the movie generates into something more than just an average teen comedy. <br />The laughs are almost non-stop, filled with a sense of humor that has great taste and tact. Much of this has to do with the movie's mockery of all things blonde, while at the same time embracing them so that the humor isn't hurtful or insulting. From pinks skirts and high heels, to a fuzzy phone and a Chihuahua that she dresses in matching outfits, Elle's persona is a riotous display of the typical air-headedness given an atypical treatment through the display of her kindness. <br />Her gentle nature and her unwillingness to give it up also gives the feel-good factor a shot in the arm of confidence. The movie covers just about every lesson you can think of, from friendship and broken hearts, to first appearances and loyalty, and takes on a moral that is good, clean fun without being overly sentimental. Take the scene in which Elle helps Paulette stand up to her ex-husband. Elle uses her technical language to completely confuse him and retrieve Paulette's dog, and the scene becomes funny and touching at the same time. <br />The sheer joy and glee one gets from watching a movie like this can be the result of nothing less than satisfaction. It brought a smile to my face and laughter to my heart, and gave me a warm feeling inside that most comedies cannot. &quot;Legally Blonde&quot; never oversteps the bounds of good humor, nor is it ever too saccharine for its own good. If nothing else, it proves the age-old saying that blondes do have more fun.

B000001FE0|5.0|There is a vast catalogue of &quot;important&quot; releases that present many pop groups and artists of The Sixties in what is arguably considered their finest hour: The Beatles' Sgt. Peppers Lonely Hearts Club Band, Strange Days by The Doors, Dear Eloise/King Midas In Reverse by The Hollies, The Velvet Underground And Nico (debut album; same title), Distant Shores by Chad and Jeremy, Crown Of Creation by Jefferson Airplane, and too many more to mention. Sadly overlooked too often by the critics is this wonderful collection of music the Bee Gees released in 1969. The songs are often quiet and reflective, the music is accompanied by the lush, majesterial sounds of a full orchestra, creating a mood of luxury and elegance. The cost factor in creating this set of music must have been quite prohibitive at the time (This was originally a 2 record set), but the Brothers Gibb were looking for a Sound, a Final Note of rare beauty and grace. You couldn't compare Odessa to any other releases of 1969, it was unique. The album bears the distinctive absence of the latest trends and gimmicks so often employed at the time (false endings, backwards tape loops, vocoder vocals, late blooming psychedelia effects), so it doesn't sound dated when you hear it today. If anything, it was a bold move for The Bee Gees to present this opus, so very unlike what everybody else was doing. There is much thought given to these songs, and the studio time was well spent. I can't really say there are any &quot;throwaway&quot; titles in the set; they all work together as the woven threads to a grand tapestry. It's an extravagant move to include 3 (!!) orchestral instrumental pieces capping the sets, but they are so right for the album, and wondrous to hear even today. I still think Odessa stands as The Finest Hour for The Bee Gees. Like a fine wine, a classic film, or the distant memory of an old love affair, it only improves with time.
B00005QDW5|4.0|What else would you expect of a compilation of such a great group?. This CD has very great sound, the feeling of any Pink Floyd LP (since the songs are connected to give a sense of unity) and even includes &quot;When the tigers broke free&quot; which I guess have been a favorite for any Floyd fan because of its rarity. And it even has a comprehensive, although edited, version of Echoes. Three flaws though: 1) Too many &quot;Division Bell&quot; songs (And no &quot;Take it Back&quot;!...Are you kidding me?). That will lead the occasional listerner to believe that this is one of the best Pink Floyd works, but the true fans know different. 2) Not so many &quot;Roger Waters&quot; songs. (That's what you get for leaving the group!). 3) Not all the albums are represented. But I was kinda surprise that there are 4 Syd Barret songs, and that's only fair to one of the masterminds that has worked in this band. Anyway, I have to believe that this is an acceptable compilation, in the face of the hardest task of all: make something representative of the extensive work by one of the greatest bands ever. Enjoy!

Silver Chair, 5. Horse/Boy, 6. Magician's Nephew, and 7. Last Battle.  <br />This puts the creation of Narnia within the context of the storyline. I don't think it would stand alone as well.<br />So, if you're planning to introduce these to your kids (and I hope you do!) consider the original sequence - I think you and your children will enjoy it more.

0451169514|5.0|Like many of Stephen King's books, &quot;It&quot; takes place in a small town in Maine called Derry. The story begins in 1957 when William &quot;Stuttering Bill&quot; Denbrough's younger brother, George, is killed by a clown in a rain gutter. His death is the first of many that will plague Derry for generations, but it's the one that will haunt Bill forever.<br />More than twenty-five years later, the pattern is being repeated--children are disappearing and occasionally found dead, brutally murdered--and one concerned citizen (Mike Hanlon) vows to put an end to it. He's responsible for contacting his six childhood friends (Bill Denbrough, Stanley Uris, Richard Tozier, Ben Hanscom, Eddie Kaspbrak, and Beverly Marsh-Rogan) and reminding them of the promise they had made together as children--to destroy IT if it were to reawaken. And it has.<br />Although the story is set in 1985, all seven friends continuously flashback on their childhood before/while/after confronting IT. The memory segments take up a great deal of the book, but I'm glad they weren't removed. Anyhow, Stephen King and brevity have never gone hand-in-hand.<br />If you're willing to read 1,000+ pages, then I highly recommend this book. It's well worth your time. But if not, I'd recommend the TV movie instead; that is, if you don't mind watching a three-hour movie. Either way, you'll be spending a considerable amount of time being scared.<br />My choice was the book. I read &quot;It&quot; back in middle school ('90 or '91), but I wouldn't necessarily encourage younger (or more sensitive) readers to try this one unless you're already familiar with Stephen King or horror novels. There is plenty of gore, profanity, and sex--everything typical of King--that might offend some people. So, consider yourself warned.

(No, he's not the chap who wrote about the Beatles). Even if he is real, did he write himself as he truly is in the book, or some abstract version? Did Gilliam take the book version of Hunter Thompson and twist him into a Gilliamesque character? We may never know. What we do know is the care with which Johnny Depp and Benicio Del Toro play Thompson and his chum Doctor Gonzo.<br />There is an intensity to Depp's performance counterbalanced by the languid Toro which demonstrates uppers and downers in all their ghastly glory. Christina Ricci makes a noteworthy appearance, proving that she isn't just a washed up child star.<br />On the whole, a very interesting and strangely compelling film, but not necessarily a pleasant experience.<br />The DVD has a ton of extras, so it's well worth the money, especially the out-takes which show us something of what the film could have been like if it was longer (it was long enough!).
630289915X|5.0|This is the kind of story that transcends all generations and ages and speaks to each individual.  It is associated with the Christmas holidays and rightly so.  Yet the movie's story about a good man who is frustrated with his life to the point of suicide speaks as loudly today as it did in 1947.<br />Some critics of &quot;It's A Wonderful Life&quot; call it &quot;Capracorn&quot; (making reference to the movie's director, Frank Capra), and say that it is unrealistic sentiment, but I disagree.  The story basically shows how a man's life unfolds through a period of years in the town in which he was born.  What he thinks are disappointments and cruel tricks of fate actually lead him to the place he always wanted to be.  He is shown what the lives of his loved ones and friends would have been like had he never been born.  He realizes that those small acts of kindness and love that he has given to people were not insignificant, but made major differences in each and every life.<br />Particularly moving is the scene where the protagonist, George Bailey, superbly played by Jimmy Stewart, prays a silent, but desparate prayer in the town bar.  The answer to that prayer gives George Bailey some unexpected twists and turns, but shows the fabric of his life is so carefully interwoven with those he loves and cares for.<br />This is American filmaking at its very finest.  I highly reccomend this for the whole family.
0517122707|5.0|Throughout the first one-hundred pages of this novel I kept wondering why such a great consensus of readers thought it so stuffed with hilarity. If verisimilitude is still a quality to be looked for in fiction, why in the world would I want to have any association with slob extraordinaire Ignatius J. Reilly! Soon enough, the choice wasn't up to me. But it wasn't because of Reilly himself; rather, it was because of all the other characters, each stringently drawn within parameters one would expect of minor characters, but all interacting with Reilly. My empathy with the main character, therefore, resulted not from Ignatius J. Reilly himself, but from the others in the book who gave me reason to appreciate this man. For most of the rest of the story I laughed the same as everyone before me.
6301797906|5.0|This isn't one of those films which need a lot of explaining to tell why they deserve to be called great.  To those who know something about John Steinbeck's novel, it is enough to say that the picture is way ahead of anything even the most hopeful had reason to expect.  It is all beautifully direct and literal, like clear-cut themes in a symphony.  There is Tom Joad, on parole from prison, going back to his family on their farm.  The shell of a farmhouse, deserted, the family blown out by dust-storms and tractor-farming.  The family, found again, setting out westward in their junky old truck, for work and a place to settle on the soil once more.   The long trek west, over the endless inter-state highways, joing the miserable stream of other families driven away from their own birthright and seeking a promised land of home and work again.  Nunnally Johnson, who wrote the screenplay, had to do something more with Steinbeck's book than cut pages out of it and paste them together.   He had to dramatise it, which meant concentrating its essence while he built it to mounting emotion and action.  If Johnson's script narrows the gist of the story to only what happens to the Joad family, director John Ford had spread it wide again, in the way that only a movie can do.  The chief thing about the acting is that it almost never seems to be acting at all.  Perhaps John Carradine and Grant Mitchell give an occasional impression of doing their stuff, but the rest, from the most casual extra to the stars, might have been caught in some episode of actual life.  Henry Fonda and Jane Darwell are the most important because they embody the main spirit of the drama: they both fill their parts with such life, that they are peerless in their playing.  There is, too Ford's fondness for mist and shadows and music-but all in their place here, integral and rarely mannered.  THE GRAPES OF WRATH proved that Hollywood could lead the world in serious as well as merely entertaining pictures; thisis a poem of a film.

B000000W5L|5.0|Ok, first off, if you are a fan of these popstar wannabes that dance around, but dont play a single note, then this is not the album for you. If you are a fan a great rock music, a member of a band, then step right up and listen to EXILE ON MAIN STREET. This album shows THE ROLLING STONES at a creative high that very few bands are ever capable of reaching. This album is the last in a string of 5 great albums stretching from 1967 to 1972. EXILE takes country, rock, blues, and gospel and weaves together a toxic sound that on first listen will have you scratching your head and wondering what you are listening. This album will take a few listens to grow on you, but it is worth it. This album is one that I find myself going back and listening to whenever I need a jolt of some great music. This album was recorded in Keith Richard's basement in France and while the production may not be top notch, the songs are. You want some great songs to listen to, then here you go: ROCKS OFF, RIP THIS JOINT, SHAKE YOUR HIPS, TUMBLING DICE, SWEET VIRGINIA, SWEET BLACK ANGEL, LOVING CUP, ALL DOWN THE LINE, SHINE A LIGHT,STOP BREAKING DOWN, and the Keith classic HAPPY. By means of concocting this visage of real movie to cover the shambles of imaginative ineptness all around it, Swordfish is only an intensely ornamented empty shell casing of film that engrosses through it's dynamic distraction of it's problems rather than through just telling a powerful story. Frankly, Swordfish is the dubious epitome of how not to make an action film. Stay away at ALL COSTS. 0553213105|5.0|As embarrassing as it sounds, I must make a confession: I, a male college student, was up till two a.m. on a Saturday finishing this book.  In short, the novel is well worth the attention of any personality type, any demographic, any fancy, any interest.  It is a marvelous story, written flawlessly, and with such a humorous personality to bind it all together that one might frequently erupt aloud in laughter.<br />The laughter, while abundant and universally entertaining, does not supercede the primary intentions of this novel, signified in the title by &quot;Pride&quot; and &quot;Prejudice.&quot;  And, indeed, in these two arenas, Austin succeeds marvelously in creating a tale that thrusts upon the reader both of these emotions, causing him to experience and be embarrassed by his own possession of these two traits.  In that case, Pride and Prejudice is a work of pure genius.  Especially with the subject of the Prejudice, the reader becomes so involved in the misconceptions and assumptions between one character and another that he is thrown through the tumultuous emotions that form the characters into more just and honorable characters at the novels conclusion.<br />Having had only Sense and Sensibility as a prior introduction to Jane Austin, I emphatically commit that Pride is the greater, more humorous, more emotionally charged, and more intellectually potent novel.  To the very degree which the reader wrongfully dislikes--even abhors--certain characters in the book, makes the conclusions finale--long awaited and anxiously feared to be tragic--the more powerful of a climax.  Never before have I read a book that so forcefully charged me to reevaluate my own convictions and prejudice of other people.  It is truly a masterwork of reader manipulation, as the characters in the book are pulled ride along side, and both the fictional and non-fictional assumptions are cast aside and replaced with shame and embarrassment.<br />In conclusion, there are so many reasons to read this book that it is impossible to deny.  Read it for the laughter, for the story, for the passion, for the irrefutable and welcome reversal that it will no doubt spur in each reader who picks the novel up.  There is so much to learn and so much fun to be had with this book, that no one should be deprived of the experience.

B00005QDW5|2.0|As an offspring of one of the biggest Pink Floyd fans out there (Mother), I have grown to love this mysterious rock band that had changed in their 30 years of existence. I think that it's about time that a collection of Floyd's best works be brought together in one album. I have pros and cons in my opinion of this album....first let's praise.<br />The album certainly covers Floyd in all it's forms; from the earliest days with Syd Barrett to the final days in Mr. Waters' absence, it's all there. The arrangement of non-chronologial order of the tracks (given year they were recorded, respectively)<BR>is an effctive method of &quot;juke-box Floyd&quot; for any fan. I also like the addition of &quot;When the Tigers Broke Free,&quot; a song previously only found in the movie &quot;The Wall&quot;...very nice touch.<br />However, I also have complaints and questons.<br />First off, and not too big a deal, is the missing seven minutes from the song &quot;Echos.&quot; The editor cleverly shortened the song so well that it's hardly noticable unless you are very keen.<BR>Okay, now here's my big objections:<br />Curiously, my favorite floyd album, along with a few others, have been left out of this collection entirely.<BR>Atom Heart Mother, Ummagumma, Obscured by Clouds (soundtrack from the film &quot;The Valley&quot;), and More (sountrack from the film &quot;More&quot;) all have no spots whatsoever on this collection.<br />Now I guess to the average Floyd listener, this is no biggie, because they may not have even known of or listened to these albums before, paying more attention to the better known albums (The Wall, Dark Side of the Moon, Wish You Were Here), it's more of a personal grudge that I have with the collection. <br />If I were a part of making this collection, I would have opted for a third CD, so as not to have been so restrictive in the amount of space for songs. A third CD would have, indeed, allowed selections from the missing albums to be present on the collection (and believe me, there are songs on all of them that are worthy of being a part of this collection), plus, room for a few songs that were left out on the other albums (Brain Damage from Dark Side, Have a Cigar from Wish You Were Here, Mother from The Wall...etc.).<br />So, in conclusion, this collection is very well done...but it could have been done better.<br />~Miggy~

0790736039|5.0|This movie rules! I'm a huge fan of the book, and I can say that the movie really does it justice. The whole story involves a group of kids, all &quot;losers&quot;, drawn together by a supernatural force to confront an ancient evil that takes the form of a malignant clown.<br />Tim Curry was, I think, born to play Pennywise the Clown. Sadistic, waddling freak with his doughy, grinning white face, red wet lips stetched as wide as his ears. In his clown form, he is able to charm the younger kinds, but he becomes the fears of the older ones, taking them down into his sewer dungeon to feed on them. The kids that finally beat the monster, Big Bill and Haystack and Bev and the rest of the Loser's Club, manage to force It back into It's lair, not dead, but nearly mortally wounded....<br />Driven by a feeding cycle, It rises again decades later, and the Loser's Club, now forgotten in adulthood, is drawn back together to face the monster one final time. This was originally made-for-television, so the movie is only capable of so much, but I think that fact alone gives the movie special merit. The casting was pretty much dead-on (especially in the case of Pennywise) and the special effects were surprisingly good. Probably the fact that the film makers were incapable of going the hack-and-slash rated-R route helped to improve the suspense and the atmosphere. The book was great, and the movie was great. I would recommend them both. I think that the humble perfection of a classic good versus evil story can sometimes be overlooked. The purity of a tale in which you can easily lose yourself. And that's just what It is. Two big thumbs up from me.

0743216458|3.0|Ambrose's account, the basis for the HBO miniseries, certainly makes interesting and often moving reading. I have been reading it bit by bit after watching each TV episode which aids my understanding of elements glossed over in the miniseries. If you've been watching Band of Brothers, reading the book will enhance the experience.<br />Sadly the quality of the writing is poor in places. All to often Ambrose slips in military acronyms for brevity that will leave regular readers without a clue as to what he is talking about. MLR, OP, CP, S2? And for what is supposed to be an historical account, the book is peppered with erroneous detail (see Dr. Forczyk's review).<br />It's a pretty much one sided tale (Think:- How E Company won the war in Europe almost single handed) which has actually lent itself very well to the TV production. It would perhaps have been better if Ambrose had written it as a dramatised &quot;based on a true story&quot; style book, rather than trying to pass it off as a definitive history. As history I'd give it 2 stars, as a fiction I'd give it 4 stars, but since it's both I'll split the difference and give it 3.
B000002N3N|3.0|To my mind, TMOT represents Enya's low water mark (excuse the pun). This was the CD that wrested me away from full devotion to her work. Not that the CD is bad. By other artists' standards this is definitely above average. But for Enya, it is simply a retread. Repackaging of previous musical ideas. Little in the way of innovation.<br />I find in reading reviews of her music that reviews fall into several categories. The lemming reviews, are those by devotees who blindly accept any of her offerings with equal fervor. The musical snobs, who castigate her work as being unsophisticated and trite. The newbies, who are hearing Enya's work for the first time and think the latest (their first exposure to Enya) is the be-all, end-all. And then there's me, the nostalgic, offering what I feel is an objective take on how a CD ranks in an artist's overall repertoire. That said, Watermark is pure genius, the best album of the last twenty-five years. Shepherd Moons is also brilliant, though inevitably a notch below its peerless predecessor. TMOT continues the slide, dipping into mediocrity, territory that Enya had never before chartered. On account of the disappointment I had with TMOT, I still haven't shelled out for her latest CD, ADWR, but I'm sure my curiosity will win out.

B000002GEV|5.0|Good Lord on toast!!! Then to go on to create some of the great commercial successes that they did in the 80's as Supertramp did, must have made Pink Floyd cringe...as well as all of their devoted fans. <br />Yeah, well, after &quot;The Wall&quot; that was pretty well it wasn't it?<BR>Even then, &quot;The Wall&quot; leaves a lot to be desired doesn't it?<br /> I can't understand why most people are so quick to lambaste and be so critical of Supertramp? Supertramp had only themselves to produce COTC and subsequent albums.<br />I have to say that COTC is one great and fantastic album and to give it any less merit would be a sin, but judge it for your self, get this album, listen to it, and for heaven's sake, please... please!!!... do not let anyone tell you this is a pop band.<br />Supertramp did go on to release &quot;Even in The Quietest Moments&quot; and &quot;Breakfast in America&quot;, but this is the direction that they chose to go. A lot had to do with the stylings of Roger Hodgson and Rick Davies and this brought them into the 80's in the fashion that they are now being rated upon, and with that being said, could be a good thing or a bad thing, depending on your personal preferences. <br />Good for them that they were able to take the people that recognized their talents and carry those as well as others that loved their musical genious and keep us enthralled with what these guys were all about. <br />To me, &quot;It's Raining Again&quot;, and &quot;The Logical Song&quot; just exemplifies how such a talent was able to come on board mainstream and attract the large numbers of fans that these kind of songs did. Do not dismiss however for one brief moment that their earlier works were &quot;pop&quot; like. The vision that they had, came forth very strongly and hearing their results are proof of that.<br />Listen to &quot;Fools Overture&quot;(off of the Even in The Quietest Moments album)... and this will give you an idea of their heartfelt compassion, their respect and love for the music and the point that they make. Even with a topic such as this, they still find a way of giving us hope through their music. (Another underated song in my opinion)... I wonder if this is considered a pop song? <br />Supertramp is not a &quot;pop&quot; band and should not be considered as such. Listen to their earlier recordings,... follow their music, and you'll see for yourselves, that these guys are more than talented. When you get to &quot;Breakfast in America&quot; enjoy it for what it is... another great album, laid down in simpler ways, but nonetheless an album full of quality songs... done by a group of extremely talented musicians.<br />Crime of the Century...<BR>...best way to hear this album?... put it on while your alone, with headphones... turn it up a bit... ENJOY!!!<br />Thanks... Kim

Opening with  why-was-this-not-a-single &quot;Supervixen&quot;, Garbage just glides by, spinning yarns of depression, religion, revenge, and stupid girls. B00002R0MC|2.0|Despite the millions upon millions of fans worldwide that swear by Robert Nesta Marley's Island Records product, none of these sides (with the exception of the recently released Jamaican mix of &quot;Catch A Fire&quot; as well as the expanded version of &quot;Exodus&quot;) really captures Marley at his best.  All of Marley's Island offerings were doctored in the studio upon receipt by Island Records owner Chris Blackwell in the U.K. (by the likes of Rolling Stones' touring keyboardist Rabbit), softening any raw roots edges to meet a more &quot;populist&quot; (read: caucasion) audience.  Although songs such as &quot;One Love&quot; have been played to death (in a manner not unlike Van Morrison's &quot;Brown Eyed Girl&quot;), Marley's 2 albums with Lee Scratch Perry have been ignored in lieu of this mediocre material.  &quot;African Herbsman&quot; and &quot;Rasta Revolution&quot; are far more indicative of a truer reggae context than the reggae-lite/pop oriented sounds contained within &quot;Songs of Freedom&quot; - do yourself a favor and investigate these 2 titles (and the embryonic Wailers on C.S. Dodd's Studio One label if so inclined); you'll be left wondering what all the fuss re: the Island era (other than the recent aforementioned reissues) is all about after a listen.  &quot;One Love&quot; indeed.
0671042858|4.0|The Girl Who loved Tom Gordon is not Stephen King's best work. Its not complicated and involved as The Stand, or as bone chilling as The Shining. But It works. The woods are a scary place, and I used to be terrified of them as a kid. The idea of a little heroine with a possibly haunted walkman is a simple formula, not too big on horror, but big on courage and faith; which is another formula used in most of King's books. Trisha joins Dolores Claiborne or Jesse from Gerald's Game in Stephen's heroine against evil club. The baseball stuff was boring, since im not a sports fan, but it did have its purpose, and the ending could have been a little more scarier, because we were expecting a big climax. But it didnt, and it is an enjoyable book nevertheless. Not laying it on too thick, horror tactics this time around were replaced with old fashioned suspense and anxeity, and thats not so bad. A good quick read, worth giving a try.

Robert DeNiro plays Jimmy Conway, a close associate, who can't ever be a \\"made\\" man because he's only half Italian.  He plays his part with a perfectly cold calculating ruthlessness.  He's loyal until the Luthtansa heist he masterminds is exploited by all the associates involved.  Conway is adamant about telling each person not to show off.  Several don't listen, so he offs each offender one by one. DeNiro's best scene is where he finds out one of his friends is killed, (I won't say who in case you've not seen this somehow),  and he is so overcome with emotion he cries hysterically while smashing a phone on the glass of an old fashioned outdoor \\"Superman\\" phonebooth and then knocking it over completely with an angry shove.
