0198534469|5.0|Needham's book is a masterpiece which will be appreciated by anyone who already has gained (or is simultaneously gaining) a firm knowledge of the traditional, i.e. more algebraic, approach to complex analysis. In addition to reading it for pleasure, I have used the book extensively in teaching 18.04 Complex Variables with Applications at MIT, not as a required textbook, but rather as inspiration for lectures and homework problems. The book helps me give the students (mostly undergraduates in applied mathematics, science, and engineering) the geometrical insights needed for a deeper understanding of the subject, beyond what is found in various standard texts, such as Churchill and Brown or Saff and Snider (the required textbook for 18.04). As a prelude or companion to Needham's book, however, I would recommend reading one of these other books and working through more  straightforward examples of algebra and calculus with complex functions.  With that said, Needham's book is a perfect supplement to a first course in complex analysis. <br />Needham's book is unique in its clear explanation of how the rich properties of analytic functions all follow from the &quot;ampli-twist&quot; concept of complex differentiation. In my class, I use this crucial, geometrical idea from the first mention of the derivative, where it goes hand in hand with the concept of conformal mapping (which is often at the back of introductory texts, but which I think should appear near the beginning). Perhaps the most delighful section of Needham's book is the one where he uses the same ampli-twist concept to give a very intuitive, unified proof of Cauchy's theorem, Morera's theorem, and the fact that a loop integral of the conjugate gives 2i times the area enclosed. The book also contains many clever and challenging problems, which are appropriate to give students to help them &quot;think outside the box&quot;, as it were. <br />The most amazing thing about Needham's book is that it is sure to delight and edify both beginners and experts alike with its simple, geometrical explanations. This is all the more impressive because geometry in mathematics education is more traditionally a vehicle to teach rigorous proofs rather than intuitive understanding.
0451204530|1.0|How could a Harvard grad, WWII veteran, spy, and engineer not know where Newport News was? The use of xeroxing has been mentioned as a reflexion of poor editing; I agree, that troubled me to the point where I wondered what other historical information was also untrue.  At one point our hero is driving a jeep on the Florida sands, the next moment he leaves his &quot;car&quot; to venture on foot. No one in 1958 called a jeep a car. Shouldn't do it now either, but back then a jeep was a four-wheel, very rugged, but very small off-road vehicle that would never have been referred to as a car. Sloppy work. No more Follet.  I actually felt sorry for his editors, I imagine they caught errors but due to publishing deadlines, the changes were not incorporated into the final book.  On the ideolgical side, too little depth to explain the motivation of those who leaned to the left. It also seemed too far fetched that a small group of young pre-war coeds in Cambridge would all play such significant roles in the major events of the world.   Try &quot;Cutout&quot; by Francine Mathews

B00003CXN4|4.0|O.k., now I guess youve already know what &quot;Traffic&quot; is all about, right ? I can assure you that &quot;Traffic&quot; contains almost no &quot;action&quot; whatsoever (there is only one brief chase at the beginning). &quot;Traffic&quot; tells three stories, has no main character the audience can rely on, and is more or less entirely based on characters and their motivations. B00004S35Z|5.0|While the phrase, &quot;greatest album&quot; is a useless distinction for the great Stevie Wonder, the material contained herein finds him at a pinnacle of his more introspective songwriting mode. Released between the chart-topping splendor of INNERVISIONS and the monumental SONGS IN THE KEY OF LIFE, FULFULLINGNESS' FIRST FINALE has spare instrumentation and a particularly personal tone.From gospel-inflected affirmations to the funky classic, &quot;Boogie On Reggae Woman,&quot; this music is spirited.<br />Stevie sings out on a seamless array of love declarations (&quot;Creepin&quot;) and social protestations (&quot;You Haven't Done Nothin&quot;). The melodies are simple and evocative, spiced with jazzy harmonies. Between his gentle clavinet work and his inspired synth romps, the man's got a great keyboard palette, and he surely knows how to use it. Throughout, Stevie provides excellent interplay between foreground andbackground, rounding out his vocal and keyboard flights with haunting overdubs. Perhaps most outstanding is the moving reverie, &quot;Heaven Is,&quot; a hand-clapping groove on the divine. Let's face it -- few soulsters can be quite as mesmerizing as Stevie with a line like, &quot;Love is so a-ma-zing.&quot;

I found very little to even smile about.<br />The lead characters, Mr. &amp; Mrs. Krank, decide to NOT do all the Christmas hoopla one year and take the money they will save and splurge it on themselves instead. Does this seem like a radical idea in this day and age to you? It didn't to me either, especially considering how commercial the holiday has become and knowing this is the first year they will be without their daughter. It made perfect sense to me. And yet not one of their acquaintainces or their circle of so-called &quot;friends&quot; offers one ounce of support for their decision. A few offer envy, that's about as close as the author comes to endorsing the Krank's view that Christmas has gotten out of control and they'd rather just<br />take a break one year from all the chaos surrounding it.<br />Are the Krank's bad people because they decide one year to spend the thousands of dollars they would normally spend on Christmas on themselves? Their neighbors and friends seem to think so and spend almost the entire book not letting them forget it.<br />This book also completely lacks any relationship between the characters and the true meaning of Christmas. It's all about parties and gifts and conspicuous and expensive wastes of money in the name of the holiday. There's no kindness or empathy or understanding among the folk who inhabit this world. And nothing of Christ at all. I also found the notion that everyone the Krank's knew or met would be so appalled by their idea. In this day and age, with the commercialization of the holiday, I think many people would sympathize with one's desire to not ride the Christmas roller-coaster once in a while.<br />But worst of all, I don't know what the author was trying to say about people or the holiday. The people act meanly toward one another throughout the book. Is that in the spirit of Christmas?And the holiday seems to be all about decorations and parties and not pleasing yourself at all, but trying endlessly to please everyone else. That doesn't seem like a recipe for holiday cheer to me. Sure, it all comes out in the end, but I found it hard to forget the hostility up to that point. By the end, I didn't care whether any of them had a nice Christmas or not.<br />If you feel you must read this book, I suggest the library. That's where I got my copy and I am very glad I did. This is not a keeper at all.n a while.<br />But worst of all, I don't know what the author was trying to say about people or the holiday. The people act meanly toward one another throughout the book. Is that in the spirit of Christmas?And the holiday seems to be all about decorations and parties and not pleasing yourself at all, but trying endlessly to please everyone else. That doesn't seem like a recipe for holiday cheer to me. Sure, it all comes out in the end, but I found it hard to forget the hostility up to that point. By the end, I didn't care whether any of them had a nice Christmas or not.<br />If you feel you must read this book, I suggest the library. That's where I got my copy and I am very glad I did. This is not a keeper at all.

B000002AZ8|2.0|It has been said that Vitalogy was the first recorded salvo in Pearl Jam's (purely mythical) mission of alienation, which many argue reaches it's conclusion with No Code. But consider if you will how far out and alienating it is to provide a young audience recently robbed of Cobain with... an album of dark, angry, riff based, mostly loud ninties rock songs. One can't help but feel that Pearl Jam could have done little more to buy into the zeitgeist, and the rough edges will surely have been nothing but a delight to those who mistrusted the smoother sound of the first two Pearl Jam records. And clearly this would not matter at all if the albums contents were worth while. But in fact this is by far Pearl Jam's laziest effort, and this lack of application manifests itself not in honest, direct communication but in half written, boringly delivered songs. Not For You could be a good song, were it not for its one riff being bludgeoned to death by repetition and its being expected to carry the song way further than a three chord motif can bare. There are some good things to be heard here: Corduroy is a Pearl Jam classic and a good song as well, suggesting that were more time and creative energies lavished upon this record, it could have been good. In actual fact it turns out that (apart from Corduroy) the best bits of Vitalogy  are the 'throw away' Bugs and Pry To, simply because they represent glimpses of interest amid what is otherwise a dull excercise in the banal, made all the worse by the fact that Pearl Jam had showed so much of merit on the first two records and now seemed determined to flush it down the toilet of grunge with the most half hearted of... [at this point the reviewer left the PC for so long that his flatmates posted the review for him anyway]

0385505833|2.0|I hate to be critical of such a well-meaning book, but it really is below mediocre.  I've never read any Grisham, so I have no idea how it stacks up against his usual, but it stacks up pretty poorly indeed against every other piece of fiction I've read in the last 2 years.<br />First, the premise is barely plausible.  Seizing on a financial motivation for &quot;skipping&quot; Christmas, the protagonist proceeds to throw out the baby with the bathwater.  Is his motivation thrift or mean-spiritedness?  Grisham makes no effort to indicate that the protagonist is mean-spirited, but without that, the plot development rings false, and the (I don't think I've giving anything away here) late conversion doesn't seem all that interesting.<br />Second, the characters are all one- or two-dimensional.  These are-- at best-- paper cutouts of people.<br />Third, and I'd have to say the crucial failing for me, was the utter flatness of the dialogue.  This is the Tom Clancy school of dialogue.  There wasn't a single laugh for me in the book, although Grisham was clearly trying to make it whimsical.  The dialogue was almost exclusively exposition, yielding little insight into the characters.<br />Two stars, one for being about Christmas and one for being readable (and probably writeable) in a single sitting.  It's clearly not trying to be much, and it succeeds at that.
0375703764|3.0|Danielewski wrote a long book, but I think I can provide some help with a short review.  The most striking thing about the book, perhaps besides fun visual arrangement in some chapters, is the copious amount of footnotes.  So here is my suggestion:<BR>1.  Skim the introduction, and skip it if it bores you.<BR>2.  Skip all the normal footnotes with dates and names.<BR>3.  Skim read all the personal footnotes of Johny Truant- marked by the shift in typeset.  Many times you can skip whole paragraphs and still get the jest of what is being said.<BR>4.  Read the body of the Navidson record, carefully at times- but if you feel like you're getting bogged down, skimming large sections here won't hurt either.<br />I think this is fair because the footnotes, in my opinion, are meant to impress by their sheer volume, not their content.  I spent twenty bucks on this book and at first I thought I had wasted my money, not making any progress for two months.  But when I read it following the criteria above, I was able to finish the book in a week and I really began to enjoy it.  By the way, the book should really be rated 3.5 stars, plus I'm not into horror or sci-fi, so for a fan of this genre, the rating might go even higher.<BR>P.S. No one gets as much anonymous sex as J.T. and his friend Lude, but it was still fun to read.

B00005QK3W|5.0|After listening to the album four times, my initial impression is that it sounds like a distant cousin to the RAM album. There                             is that kind of casual, let's-do-it-and-not-think-too-much-about-it quality about it, which in general recalls Paul's early 70's                                albums. True to this spirit, some of the songs are slight (Your Way, Driving Rain) but still very catchy. Songwriting has always come easy to Paul, you see, and occasionally he just doesn't feel the need to come up with a middle eight or a &quot;bridge&quot; to properly finish off a song. <BR>     The production is, in my opinion, a vast improvement over the last album. The vibe is warm and organic, the natural                          sounding drums are much more suitable to Paul's music than Jeff Lynne's monster snare hits on Flaming Pie. If you own                             any other McCartney albums then you know what to expect lyrics-wise. The guy never did compete with Shakespeare, you                              know, and with an exception of couple of poignant moments, the words are merely pleasant and passable. <BR>      But it doesn't matter, because that familiar Paul McCartney vibe, that melodic spark which we all love so much, is still there. And curiously, there are several deeply melancholic moments here that carry genuine emotion: From A Lover To A Friend,                                She's Give Up Talking in particular both have a strange, haunting quality to them. Lonely Road starts out calmly and builds effectively into a desperate growler. Heather is a beautiful, euphoric piece which captures the rush of falling in love with someone. My version of the album comes with a bonus track -- a live recording of &quot;Freedom&quot; from the New York City benefit. It's quite rousing, and Paul's vocal sounds much stronger than I remember it from watching the show on TV. <BR>     In the end, if you don't like McCartney, this album won't convert you. But for the diehards, this is an embarrassement of                                riches. Is this on par with his classic stuff? Have no idea. If it was released in 1972, I have a feeling the album would probably top the charts, and it would spawn two top ten singles. Today, radio won't touch it and most people will not even know it's out. But, hey, it's just great to hear from the man every once in a while. Favorite songs: Lonely Road, Heather, From A Lover To A Friend, She's Giving Up Talking, Driving Rain, Your Way, I Do.

0060001941|5.0|I think I finally understand my younger sister who is in her forties today.  She read this book when she was the age of eight or nine and living in New York City.  I recall her talking about how wonderful the book was and how much she enjoyed Francie and aunt Sizzy.  Like Francie (including myself), she grew up in similar circumstances except there were six siblings and mother.  Dad was too irresponsible to fit any of the characters, except perhaps the disgruntled Willie Flittman, who runs off with his new found vocation; a single man orchestra (substitute women).  Anyhow, she grew into Sizzy more than Francie although there was a lot of Francie in her as a young girl.  I certainly went off in search of the American dream.  My sister did not, although Francie still lives in her particularly in her search for beauty, love, and insatiable love for books.  She too wanted to read all of the books in the local library.  <br />The book speaks mounds of truth about poverty and the struggle faced by urban poor.  Ms. B. Smith treats the subject and the characters with great tenderness and honesty.  Although the pathos and ethos of the urban poor may not have been of great interest or even palatable to readers at the time of the book's publication, the great human paradigm and its redeeming values is timeless and relevant.  Reading A Grows in Brooklyn and having lived in Brooklyn Heights as well as experienced a similar childhhod is especially welcoming.  To reflect on those difficult childhood times is important as it helps keep me grounded.  I would not deny or exchange that experience for anything in the world.  <br />The book is a must read for all lovers of literature regarless of age, gender, or socioeconomic circumstances.

0140143505|5.0|This little collection of numerous letters back and forth across an ocean at a time when 'globalization' was just beginning to find its definition shows at the very best how words alone, when chosen carefully, can give birth to a relationship that will soon be treasured. If e-mail messages have begun to grate, here is a book that will remind you how sweet letterwriting can be and how wonderful a thing it can accomplish...if one only takes the time. 84, Charing Cross, I've concluded, is also the perfect gift for friends with sensitive souls who already seem to have everything. It is also a fine thing to read before turning off the light next to your bed.

Hello?)<br />I did like it because it's a very sweet book that has an interesting moral quandary in it -- what is our duty to others?  Ourselves?  Who takes priority? The characters are very well drawn, the world is atmospheric, and the logic of the universe is extremely tight and interesting. Furthermore, the prose is good! I recommend this book extremely highly to anyone. It is so good that it does not deserve to be regarded only as genre fiction.

B000001FTD|5.0|Before this album, Anthrax were just a bunch of speed metal jokesters from NYC who had a thing for comic books.  But with the slow rise of Metallica (who were more influenced by NWOBHM than punk), Anthrax's dominance in heavy metal would soon come.  AMONG THE LIVING is the band's third album which showed how tight they had become with the inclusion of Joey Belladonna (who replaced the first singer from the FISTFUL OF METAL album).  The power riffs of Scott Ian are sick, and who could forget the power of Charlie Benante's drumming?  This man should've had eight legs.<br />While they still got into comic books (&quot;I Am The Law&quot; is about Judge Dredd), they also dealt with the original occupants of the United States (&quot;Indians&quot;), double-faced people (&quot;Imitation Of Life&quot;), and their love of Stephen King novels (&quot;A Skeleton In The Closet&quot;).  Most bands around this time were about speed and shock value, the only thing shocking about Anthrax was the whiteness of Scott Ian's legs!  But they could play, oh could they play, and didn't sacrifice skills for speed.  Their future efforts would be mixed affairs, but this albums easily stands as one of the best of all time.
B000001FN3|5.0|The Alan Parsons Project's TALES OF MYSTERY AND IMAGINATION is one of the best horror-themed rock albums ever produced.  Every track is based on a work by that master of the morbid, Edgar Allan Poe, and the band--actually only two musician-songwriters, Alan Parsons and Eric Woolfson, backed up by some outstanding session musicians--does a fantastic job of weaving Poe's eerie narrative and lurid atmosphere into a macabre musical tapestry.<br />Some of Poe's best works are interpreted here, not the least of which are &quot;The Raven,&quot; &quot;The Tell-Tale Heart,&quot; and &quot;The Fall of the House of Usher.&quot;  The more widely-known piece on the album is probably &quot;The Raven,&quot; having been granted a lot of radio play when it debuted in the 1970s,  and &quot;The Tell-Tale Heart&quot; stylistically stands as the album's most traditional rock-and-roll song.  But from an aesthetic standpoint, &quot;The Fall of the House of Usher&quot; is undoubtedly the best track.  The entire song lasts for more than 16 minutes, contains no lyrics (other than a newly added voiceover at the beginning), and is divided into different movements in much the same way as a classical symphony.  Like the Poe story that inspired it, it runs the gamut of human emotion, starting off with a serene yet melancholy classical passage, then seamlessly moving through jazzy new-age and rock segues towards an intense symphonic crescendo.  When listening to the song from start to finish, it is impossible to NOT feel that sense of inexorable deterioration and downfall that is inherent to the Poe work, and it is altogether quite artistically satisfying.<br />TALES OF MYSTERY AND IMAGINATION was originally released in 1976 and was, to the dismay of some fans, re-released a few years later with different jacket illustrations.  Though the remixed and remastered CD version reviewed here uses the original jacket art for the cover and liner illustrations, there are other aspects of the disc that will nonetheless upset fans who are &quot;purists.&quot;  For example, musical passages such as guitar riffs or background synths have been blatantly superimposed onto some of the tracks, and many of the tracks are now tied together with narrative voice-overs recorded by the late Orson Welles (yes, THAT Orson Welles).  However, one must bear in mind that these alterations have been executed by none other than Alan Parsons and Eric Woolfson themselves, and they claim to have done everything possible to ensure that the music contains the same spirit that endeared it to fans when it was originally released in 1976.<br />Still, musically speaking, the album has undergone a noticeable facelift.  Of course, if this CD represents your first exposure to the music, the changes probably won't matter to you in the least.  But if you're someone who has loved the album since its original debut, you'll just have to give this version a listen and decide for yourself if the changes either deface or enhance.  To most fans, though, the album will most certainly remain a classic.<br />This CD is highly recommended to fans of horror, those who love the works of Edgar Allan Poe, and anybody who fondly remembers the concept rock of the 1970s.ll nonetheless upset fans who are &quot;purists.&quot;  For example, musical passages such as guitar riffs or background synths have been blatantly superimposed onto some of the tracks, and many of the tracks are now tied together with narrative voice-overs recorded by the late Orson Welles (yes, THAT Orson Welles).  However, one must bear in mind that these alterations have been executed by none other than Alan Parsons and Eric Woolfson themselves, and they claim to have done everything possible to ensure that the music contains the same spirit that endeared it to fans when it was originally released in 1976.<br />Still, musically speaking, the album has undergone a noticeable facelift.  Of course, if this CD represents your first exposure to the music, the changes probably won't matter to you in the least.  But if you're someone who has loved the album since its original debut, you'll just have to give this version a listen and decide for yourself if the changes either deface or enhance.  To most fans, though, the album will most certainly remain a classic.<br />This CD is highly recommended to fans of horror, those who love the works of Edgar Allan Poe, and anybody who fondly remembers the concept rock of the 1970s.

B00005QXXO|5.0|\\"Live is where we live!\\" where the words of U2's Larry Mullen Jnr. after they had won an Mtv award for best live act in 1997.<BR>I think this quote fits very well with Radiohead, and especially with their songs!<BR>As most of us know by now, Radiohead have been exploring new musical territories on their last two albums \\"Kid A\\" and \\"Amnesiac\\".<BR>One very good thing about these explorations was the somehow naive and honest way in which they where performed.<BR>Radiohead is not about making commercial sell out records. Radiohead is not about being \\"intentionally difficult\\" or \\"avantgarde\\" or whatever. Radiohead is about music. And that's all! The important thing is music itself and not all these labels which we put on music. <BR>They never pretended to be experts in the field of electronic music. They never pretended to be experts in jazz. Yet they <BR>went on a journey into these musical genres and used elements from them as a catapult, an inspiration, for something new and unique.<br />\\"Kid A\\" was probably the darker, moodier record with disturbing soundscapes and icy techno/electronica. Examples: \\"Everything in it's right place\\", \\"Kid A\\", \\"Treefingers\\" and \\"Idioteque\\".<BR>\\"Amnesiac\\" was the brighter twin, though it had some dark moments as well. This record included several jazz explorations. That does not mean boring (...)standard jazz, but as I mentioned before elements of the genre used as a catapult for something entirely unique. Some songs that showcase this: \\"Pyramid Song\\", \\"You and whose army?\\", \\"Knives Out\\" and \\"Life in a Glasshouse\\".<br />And now...the live album. \\"I might be wrong - live recordings\\" contains eight tracks, and this is where the songs \\"come to life\\". <BR>\\"The National Anthem\\" is a noisy explosion of fuzz bazz and psychotic sounds allowing the song to rock on into another dimension without the \\"honks\\" of the horns found on the studio version. The rock continues on \\"I might be wrong\\" which is dirty distorted guitar rock in its live form.<BR>\\"Morning Bell\\" proves my suspicion one again. Phil Selway is an AWESOME drummer! This is concentrated groove at its best! A great track, slightly remminiscent of the album version, yet here the guitars have more space and therefore they sound more \\"freaky\\"....kind of.<BR>\\"Idioteque\\" is intense and rocking with real drums alongside Jonny Greenwoods syncopated synth beats.<BR>\\"Dollars and Cents\\" and \\"Everything in its right place\\" are also great and quite different from the album versions. \\"Dollars and Cents\\" is stripped of the fat strings and the heavy echo/reverb of the studio version and this leaves more space for the guitar, which simply sounds great!<BR>\\"Everything...\\" is very interesting in that Greenwood samples Thom Yorke's voice live, using a Korg sampler. This creates an amazing effect of several layers of vocals being cut up and put together. This shows how you can use technology to create an awesome dynamic live effect.<BR>I have seen Radiohead perform this song live, and towards the end they stop playing and leave everything to the sampler and the effect boxes. Humans give in, technology takes over. Yet this is using technology in a positive, inventive way.<BR>Two surprises are on the disc as well. The first is \\"Like Spinning Plates\\" which is a beautiful piano/keyboard driven tune here, unike the studio version with its backward vocals and weird sounds. <BR>The 2nd surprise is \\"True Love Waits\\", an incredible song which finally has found its way to an actual release. This is just Thom on vocals and acoustic guitar. Just one more proof that they can still write and perform beautiful songs and maybe and indication of what the future has to offer?<BR>Anyways, I'll be looking forward to it!<br />We're getting to the end now, just one more final note before I leave you:<BR>the day when I bought \\"Live recordings\\". This was monday 12th 2001 and I went into a Virgin Megastore in London to see if they had gotten the album. While I was there I noticed a big screen which showed a stage in basement section. The basement was full of young screaming girls. I got the cd and went to see what all the fuzz was about. Suddenly the screaming got a whole lot louder and Westlife (!) appeared on stage. They started singing and I stood there for a while thinking \\"so this is Westlife?\\" (I had to ask someone who they were when they appeared on stage).<BR>Anyway, they (weren't good) and you couldn't really hear anything because of the screaming girls so I left...<BR>On my way home I noticed a newspaper headline at a newstand, which read \\"Jet crashes in New York\\". My first thought was \\"what? not again!?\\".<BR>This is a strange world we live in. Plastic and commercialism. War and terrorism.<BR>Apparently everything isn't in its right place. But we are allowed to dream!<BR>thank you.

B00005Q45W|4.0|I'm loath to give this album less than five stars, but I want to express dissatisfaction with the music.<br />Lyrically, Cohen has not skipped a beat.  The theme of the tension between the sacred (my secret life) and the profane(Babylon, Boogie Street) that runs through all of Cohen's work is here present in spades.  In this respect, Ten New Songs might be his most &quot;intimate&quot; or &quot;spiritual&quot; album yet.  And the words are wonderful, laden with Cohen's familiar alchemy of levitical gravitas (&quot;In streams of light I clearly saw the dust you seldom see, out of which the Nameless makes a Name for one like me&quot;) and puckish mischief (&quot;I fought against the bottle, but I had to do it drunk&quot;).  Five stars for the words.<br />But the music...Leonard, what were you thinking?<br />I've read in various interviews that the synth music on this album was originally intended to be replaced with &quot;real&quot; instrumental music, and that Cohen fell in love with the synth and insisted on keeping it.  That was a bad decision.  The album sounds like a really good demo for ten really great songs.<br />Why, oh why, mister Cohen, did you not let Bob Metzger go to work on these great new songs?  It's not too late -- get back in the studio with some musicians and put real accompaniment behind these delicious words.  I, for one, will buy the album again.
B00005QXXO|5.0|radiohead fans have been waiting for a good long while for some official live recordings, and radiohead has, after a long, fruitful, groundbreaking series of records, finally delivered, surprising us as usual by releasing it so soon after amnesiac, released so soon after kid a. i might be wrong has just eight tracks, seven of which are from the most two recent discs and one of which is an previously unreleased rarity that fans die to hear.<br />the album is everything we could have expected from radiohead. terrific sound quality, perfect versions of eight perfect songs (standouts are the nearly-8-minute version of everything in its right place, with thom's voice distorted nearly beyond belief, and the intense idioteque), and a pleasant memory for anyone - like me - blessed enough to have seen them on their most recent tour. i saw all of these songs and i couldn't have asked for a better representation of what it was like to see this phenomenal band.<br />thanks, radiohead - we can't wait for the next disc. i know i'll be waiting.
B0000042H4|5.0|I was one of those listeners who objected to this Ring Cycle for many years. I regarded Solti's conducting as loud and unsubtle, and the engineering as gimicky to the point of detracting from the music. I also objected to the use of some singers clearly at the end of their prime, Hotter and Windgassen. Now, after hearing the remastered set, I have done a complete about-face. It may be that the remastered sound is cleaner and leaner than that on the original LP's and tape editions, but I no longer find this sound overblown or unsubtle. True, Solti is explosive at times, but appropriately so; his Walkuere actually reminds me of Furtwaengler's at many points. And like Furtaengler and Knappertsbusch, Solti gives us a very dark and subdued Act 1 of Walkuere that only brightens at the very end, as it should. He captures all the mystery of the work, as well as its excitement, much more clearly on this new remastering. I no longer find Hotter to be a disappointment; on the contrary, despite some moments of strain and unsteadiness, I find this the most moving portrayal of the role of Wotan I have ever heard, even more so than Hotter's other recordings of the role. And Windgassen now sounds more vital and vibrant than before, almost as much as he did in the 1956 Knappertsbusch Ring from Bayreuth. As for the other singers, they are all admirable, some ideal. I still wish that Hotter had done Wotan throughout this cycle, but I admit that George London comes mighty close to this standard in Rheingold. Of course, the actual recorded sound is NOT a reproduction of the Bayreuth sound, with the recessed orchestra supporting the singer, but rather with the singers very much blended in the orchestral texture. It seems now more clear that Decca was not trying to create the feeling of a live performance in the theater, but rather bring the drama into the listener's living space. Perhaps this very immediacy is what alienated me from this recording for so long. I would never want to be without a Bayreuth Ring, but this one is also indespensible in its own unique way.<br />Having heard the boxed set from Germany, I think it is even superior to the remastered USA sets of the individual operas. The blary and brassy sound originally on the LP issues has vanished altogether in favor of an airy transparency. I now can hear great subtlety as well as muscle in Solti's conducting; as I said, he sounds more like Furtwaengler or Knappertsbusch than the brash conductor I thought I had earlier heard. His Immolation Scene at the end of Goetterdaemmerung brought me to tears; Solti moves the heart as well as the senses. Windgassen is surely the most sensitive and vulnerable Siegfried along with Max Lorenz (I am NOT a Melchior lover), Nilsson is at her most intense and noble, easily the equal of Astrid Varnay, Hotter, despite being past his prime, is the most heartbreaking Wotan I have ever heard, Ludwig the most outraged and imperious Fricka (Flagstad in Rheingold is not quite her equal, being a bit too placid), Frick is the most powerfully evil Hagen and Hunding, King and Crespin the loviest Waelsung twins, and Fischer-Dieskau finally rescues Gunther to his full tragic height. And Neidlinger remains the ne plus ultra Alberich.<br />Some critics and listeners have regarded Solti's &quot;Walkuere&quot; as the weakest part of his &quot;Ring.&quot; Frankly, I have never understood the reason for this; even when I was not fond of the overall Solti cycle, I always treasured this &quot;Walkuere.&quot; Like Furtwaengler and Knappertsbusch, Solti gives us a somber, subdued First Act, with broad tempi, that only opens up and comes to life at the end. This is perfectly consistent with the dramatic situation. But it is the Second Act in which Solti really hits the mark. Like Furtwaengler, he sees the Second Act, and particularly Wotan's long monologue, as the pivotal event of the Ring, where Wotan finally sees the futility of his plans and abandons himself to his ruinious fate, destroying Siegmund and Sieglinde along with him (and later on, Siegfried as well). Having heard Solti and Furtwaengler do this Act, I find it impossible to regard it as an impediment to the drama. Solti is grave and somber here, again with braod tempi that allow the music its time and space. And with Hotter at his interpretive greatest, this Act cannot fail to impress with its greatness. (Incidentally, I rememeber an early review of this set stating that &quot;No other Wotan in history has mastered the role as profoundly as Hotter.&quot; Certainly, no other Wotan in my experience, including Hotter in his other recorded performances, expresses the anguish and finally the explosive anger as in this performance.)In the Prelude to this Act, Solti begins it in the same vein as the First Act ended, with febrile passion, but as the music changes to the hammering Walkuere motiv, he not only broadens the tempo, but changes the orchestral coloring to something much more massive, monumental. We are leaving the realm of mortals to enter the cosmic world of the Gods, as the human drama is revealed as a part of the larger divine one; Solti understands this broadening of the dramatic scope at this point and underlines it perfectly.<br />It should be obvious by now that this is a &quot;Ring&quot; for the ages, and belongs in every serious collection of classical music.estroying Siegmund and Sieglinde along with him (and later on, Siegfried as well). Having heard Solti and Furtwaengler do this Act, I find it impossible to regard it as an impediment to the drama. Solti is grave and somber here, again with braod tempi that allow the music its time and space. And with Hotter at his interpretive greatest, this Act cannot fail to impress with its greatness. (Incidentally, I rememeber an early review of this set stating that &quot;No other Wotan in history has mastered the role as profoundly as Hotter.&quot; Certainly, no other Wotan in my experience, including Hotter in his other recorded performances, expresses the anguish and finally the explosive anger as in this performance.)In the Prelude to this Act, Solti begins it in the same vein as the First Act ended, with febrile passion, but as the music changes to the hammering Walkuere motiv, he not only broadens the tempo, but changes the orchestral coloring to something much more massive, monumental. We are leaving the realm of mortals to enter the cosmic world of the Gods, as the human drama is revealed as a part of the larger divine one; Solti understands this broadening of the dramatic scope at this point and underlines it perfectly.<BR>It should be obvious by now that this is a &quot;Ring&quot; for the ages, and belongs in every serious collection of classical music.
0875845851|5.0|This is a book is about successful, well-led companies -often market leaders- that carefully pay attention to what customers need and that invest heavily in new technologies, but still loose their market leadership suddenly. This can happen when disruptive technologies enter the stage. Most technologies improve the performance of existing products in relation to the criteria which existing customers have always used. These technologies are called sustaining technologies. Disruptive technologies do something different. They create an entirely new value proposition. They improve the performance of the product in relation to new performance criteria. Products which are based on disruptive technologies are often smaller, cheaper, simpler, and easier to use. However, the moment they are introduced, they can not at once compete against the traditional products and so they cannot directly reach a big market. Christensen researched how disruptive technologies have developed in the computer disk industry, an extremely rapid evolving industry. He identified six steps in the emergence of disruptive technologies:<br />1. Disruptive technologies often are invented in traditional large companies. Example: at Seagate Technology, the biggest producer of 5,25 disks, engineers in 1985 designed the first 3,5 disk.<br />2. The marketing department examines first reactions from important customers to the new technology. Then they notice that existing customers are not very interested and they conclude that not a lot of money can be made with the new product. Example: this is what happened at Seagate. The 3,5 disk's were put upon the shelf.<br />3. The company keeps on investing in the traditional technology. Performance improvement of the traditional technology is highly appreciated by existing customers and a lot of money is being made. Example: Seagate invested in the 5,25 disk technology. This led to considerable improvement of the technology and to a considerable improvement of sales.<br />4. New companies are started up (by ex-employees of the traditional companies) and markets for the new technology emerge by trial and error. Example: ex-Seagate people started up Corner Peripherals. This company focused on the small emerging market for 3,5 inch disks. In the beginning this was only for the laptop market.<br />5. The new players move up in the market. The performance of the new technologies gets better after some time, enabling them to compete better and better with the traditional companies and products. Example: the performance of the 3,5 disks improved drastically. The 3,5 inch disk moved up in the market, to the personal computer market. Corner pushed Seagate out of the PC market for 3,5 inch disk drives.<br />6. Traditional companies try to defend their market position and to get along in the new market. Often they notice that they have fallen behind so far, that they cannot keep up. Example: Seagate did not succeed in capturing a significant part of the new market for 3,5 inch disk drives for PC's.<br />The events described above can be understood by the four principles of disruptive technologies which Christensen formulates:<br />1. In well-led companies it is customers, not managers, who actually determine resources allocation. This is a proposition of the resources dependence theory (Pfeffer &amp; Salancik, 1978) which is supported strongly by the research of Christensen. In essence: middle managers will not tend to invest in technologies that are not directly appreciated by important (large) clients, because they will not be able to get quick financial gains by doing this.<br />2. Small markets can not fulfil the growth need of large companies. For several reasons, growth is important for companies. Unfortunately, the bigger the company, the harder it is to continue growth. A small company (40 million sales) with a growth target of 20%, must achieve 8 million extra sales. A large company (4 billion sales), has to achieve 800 millionof extra sales! Emerging markets often simply are not large enough to fulfil such growth needs. They can, however, fulfil the growth needs of new small companies.<br />3. Markets that do not exist can not be analysed. The ultimate applications of disruptive technologies can not be foreseen on forehand. Failure is an intrinsic unavoidable step to success.<br />4. Technology supply does not always equal the market demand. The speed of technological progress is often bigger than the speed with which the customer demand develops. By improving the performance of the disruptive technologies (for instance the 3,5 inch disks, first only used in the laptop market), they became suitable for the larger PC-market.<br />These steps explain why traditional companies are often not capable of applying disruptive technologies. Christensen argues that you can not resist these four principles. What you can do however, is use them to your advantage. For instance: in a large company you can create an 'island' where the new technology is developed for the new market. Also it is possible get an ownership in emerging companies which develop the new technologies (several companies have done this successfully).<br />I think the innovator's Dilemma is an excellent book. The ideas are empirically foudend and together they form a coherent theoretical framework. The examples from the computer disk industry, the steel industry and others, are very well-documented and interesting. The book is logically structured and reads easily.0 million of extra sales! Emerging markets often simply are not large enough to fulfil such growth needs. They can, however, fulfil the growth needs of new small companies. <br />3. Markets that do not exist can not be analysed. The ultimate applications of disruptive technologies can not be foreseen on forehand. Failure is an intrinsic unavoidable step to success. <br />4. Technology supply does not always equal the market demand. The speed of technological progress is often bigger than the speed with which the customer demand develops. By improving the performance of the disruptive technologies (for instance the 3,5 inch disks, first only used in the laptop market), they became suitable for the larger PC-market. <br />These steps explain why traditional companies are often not capable of applying disruptive technologies. Christensen argues that you can not resist these four principles. What you can do however, is use them to your advantage. For instance: in a large company you can create an 'island' where the new technology is developed for the new market. Also it is possible get an ownership in emerging companies which develop the new technologies (several companies have done this successfully). <br />I think the innovator's Dilemma is an excellent book. The ideas are empirically foudend and together they form a coherent theoretical framework. The examples from the computer disk industry, the steel industry and others, are very well-documented and interesting. The book is logically structured and reads easily.
B00003CXXJ|5.0|&quot;Shrek&quot; is a completely entertaining film. There are so many references to the Disney-ification of all things, not to mention the Great Mouse's hijacking of all Germanic fairy tales, that its a wonder Eisner &amp; Co. didn't sue. All the vocal talents are spot on. And the bonuses on the DVD are also worthwhile- I particularly liked the interviews with the cast members. I personally look forward to Fiona and Snow White remaking &quot;Thelma &amp; Louise&quot;.<br />This is NOT a kid's movie, despite it being animated. It is, in the Jay Ward tradition, a fractured fairy tale. And, along with &quot;Memento&quot;, the best thing I've seen so far in '01.
B00005QK3W|5.0|All I can say is &quot;WOW!&quot;  I really don't know how to start, other than to say that once again, Paul McCartney is showing the world that he can still rock out!  I've waited to hear this CD, and finally I have it in my grasps and I can't stop listening to it!  The first song, &quot;Lonely Road,&quot; is a great opener to an album, and the production is great!  &quot;From A Lover To A Friend&quot; shares the sentiment, I think, that all of us go through when you've lost a relationship and then find someone you'd like to get to know a little better.  &quot;She's Given Up Talking&quot; has a nice sound to it - I love the voice effects!  Only a Beatle could do a song like &quot;Driving Rain&quot; and pull it off and make it sound wonderful.  Again, it just has that new sound to it.  &quot;Back In The Sunshine&quot; is one of my favorites, as is &quot;I Do,&quot; which I think might rank up there as Paul's next &quot;Maybe I'm Amazed.&quot;  In fact, I really can't say which songs are better than the others.  With Paul it seems that a tragic event (like the death of John Lennon or his wife Linda) always helps his songwriting, and this time is no exception.  And then with his new girlfriend Heather, Paul has even more of a muse to write about.  In fact, maybe &quot;Magic&quot; is my favorite song on the disc because it's about Paul and Linda.  <br />Paul has a very modern sound on the disc, for lack of a better term.  The band members are, I believe, in their early to mid-twenties, so maybe that is part of the reason the sound is so different to what we've heard from Paul before.  The production, I think, is slick.  I hope that many people my age will discover this album.  This isn't a Britney sounding music, it's Paul.  And as John Lennon once said, &quot;It's Paul McCartney music, and it's good music.&quot;<br />Also, I would like to add one little thought.  The song &quot;Freedom,&quot; which was written after the September 11 attacks on the World Trade Center and Pentegon is included though on these first pressings it isn't mentioned on the track list, just on a sticker on the front of the case.  While it's not a &quot;Yesterday&quot; or &quot;Hey Jude,&quot; the song does have a strong cause behind it that helps it out a lot.  It's a nice &quot;bonus&quot; track, though it doesn't quite fit with the rest of the album.  Overall, this is well worth picking up and buying!  You can't go wrong!

B00005R2M3|4.0|Laundry Services is the album meant to break this wildly talented Columbian singer into English-language stardom.  I think that it does so admirably; however, potential buyers should be aware that it is most defintely the product of a savy, mainstream music industry marketing machine.  As such, it's songs are uniformly over-produced (a charge that is true of the vast majority of MTV-driven pop).  The rhythm tracks are inexorably uniform and tight, and every vocal nuance of Shakira's powerful instrument has been analyzed, homogenized, codified, harmonized and sanitized for your protection.<br />What separates Shakira from the pack , however, is that she is the real deal.  Yes, her vocal stylings have been influenced by Alanis Morisette.  Yes, her current hair and wardrobe make her appear to be yet another Britney, and Christina, and Mandy wannabe.  Yes, she has overt popstar ambitions, and has been accused of plagarism in the past.  <br />But she *can* write.  <br />And she *can* sing.<br />Lyrically, Shikira is finding a her voice in a new language on this album.  It's easy to dismiss her English as simplistic; however, I assure you it's not easy to speak simply in poetry or song.  Her subject matter on this album tends toward the usual pop fare of sex, love and jealousy.  Shakira's lyrics are servicable on this album, but it remains impressive that she even assayed the challenge to write this album largely in English (four tracks remain in Spanish, two of which are the same tunes as earlier tracks on the CD).  As a bonus, we get an earlier Spanish hit (Ojos Asi) by Shakira in English with lyrics by Gloria Estefan.<br />Musicallly, Shakira writes tunes which incorporate a wide spectrum of influences including pop, rock, latin and middle eastern music.  With the help of the musical industrial complex behind her, this album includes tango-accordians, surf-rock twangs and the ever-popular South American pan-pipe.  For me, the album kind of sags in the middle after thethird track &quot;Whenever, Wherever&quot; until the aforementioned &quot;Ojos Asi&quot; kicks in on track ten.  Nevertheless, there are at least three new, memorable and remarkable singles on this album.<br />Vocally, Shakira continues to shine.  She has amazing control, vocal flexibility (yes, there is more to that ability than the yodeling she's accused of) and can affect a wide range of timbre.  She has a great dynamic range, and an okay frequency range.<br />All in all, I have enjoyed this album alot after buying it today.  Shakira has tremendous talent, and one hopes that it will not be destroyed by the fame that she and the marketing machine behind her are pursuing.

B00005QK3W|5.0|Driving Rain is Paul McCartney's first album of new material since 1997's Flaming Pie.  In between he released an album of covers Run Devil Run that was recorded shortly after the loss of his wife and soul mate, Linda.  That album was the most emotional of his career.  While Driving Rain isn't quite as emotional, it still has a certain weight to it.  There are some of his classic, light and breezy tunes &quot;Tiny Bubble&quot; and the laconic &quot;Spinning On An Axis&quot;.  Much like &quot;Lovely Linda&quot; from his first solo album, &quot;Heather&quot; is an ode to the new love of his life Heather Mills.  The album's best tracks are laced with an emotional weight.  &quot;Lonely Road&quot; has a frenzied edge, &quot;From A Lover To A Friend&quot; has is filled with anxiety and &quot;There Must Have Been Magic&quot; is filled with longing rememberances of the past.  &quot;Your Way&quot; has a country flavor and &quot;Rinse The Raindrops&quot; is a ten plus minute workout that shows off some nice cohesion from the spry four piece band Mr. McCartney assembled for the album.  Throughout the record, Mr. McCartney plays some of the best bass lines he's played in years and he reminds us that he is, in fact, a true legend.
B000002I25|5.0|It sure is a pleasure to reminisce, back to a day when we really thought that &quot;all you need is love&quot; and everything would be all right. Yes, the time between my 14th and 15th birthdays, when Sergeant Pepper was redefining what was musically possible and everyone else was reacting to it. &quot;Light My Fire&quot; indeed!<br />For Jim Morrison and the Doors, it was an unbelievably creative time, as evidenced by the songs on this, their first album. To say there is not a bad track here only begins to communicate the importance of the record. Some at the time called them America's Dionysian counterparts to the Rolling Stones, and that's a good place to start. Let's just say the Doors showed what could happen when &quot;California Dreams&quot; turned into nightmares, as &quot;The End&quot; so aptly describes.<br />The gem here remains &quot;Light My Fire&quot;, every bit as incandescent as when I first heard it all those 34 years ago during the &quot;Summer of Love.&quot; Of course, we're talking about what we then called the &quot;FM Version&quot; with its soaring keyboard and guitar break in the middle. The album snaps, crackles and pops with the bluesy &quot;Break on Through&quot;, &quot;Back Door Man&quot;, &quot;Take It as It Comes&quot;, and such fine rock standards as &quot;Alabama Song&quot;, &quot;Twentieth Century Fox&quot; and &quot;Soul Kitchen&quot;. Another favorite of mine is the softer &quot;Crystal Ship&quot;, and of course, &quot;The End&quot;, which later gained new fame from its appearance in the film &quot;Apocolypse Now&quot; (a particularly poignant use of the song I might add).<br />Another reviewer called this one of the four or five best rock albums of the 1960's. (I'm inclined to agree with that, but completing that list is a difficult chore indeed!) Simply put, Morrison's later death in 1971 would rob the music world of perhaps many other great works to come. For the Doors, only L.A. Woman rivaled this one creatively.
B00005QXXO|4.0|On Radiohead's previous two albums, Kid A &amp; Amnesiac, the band created sonic landscapes that featured multi-layered sounds.  They threw everything snap, crackle and pop they find into creating the sound collage.  The eight songs on I Might Be Wrong don't try to recreate their album's counterparts' sound. The band just plays the music with the instruments they've got and it shows they are just as powerful live as in the studio.  Lead singer Thom Yorke's beatbox vocal opening to &quot;The National Anthem&quot; is powerful and adds a tension to the song before he even utters a verse.  In some instances, the band leaves Mr. Yorke out on a ledge with little support.  He carries &quot;Idioteque&quot; with just sparse drum work and the album's closer, &quot;True Love Waits&quot; provides only an acoustic guitar.  Mr. Yorke's vocals are the foundation of the band's sound and the live album shows off his wonderful gifts.

Using all his skills he has to prove his innocence, find the real culprit and keep one step ahead of the authorities.<br />  The set pieces are truely dazzling, the finale on the Channel Train tunnel is absoloutly stunning and the possibly one of THE best action sequences in cinematic history.<br /> The story never slows down for a second and although at first viewing a little confusing its still gripping stuff.<br /> The supporting cast is fantastic from Jon Voight to Vanessa Redgrave it's very hard to criticise a film so well-thought out.<br /> The best action-orientated espionage film since You Only Live Twice. Shame De Palma would'nt stay for the sequel.<br /> The DVD extras are few but who cares when you've got a film this good!!!!!!

B00003CX5P|4.0|I love the STAR WARS series.  I had huge expectations for PHANTOM MENACE and was definitely let down.  Now that it's a few years later and the DVD has finally been released I still don't like the film.  It's not horrible.  The most watchable parts of the film are the final battle and the Senate scenes. For me, PHANTOM is successful in its effects, costume and set design, and political intrigue.  Lucas awed me with the Gungan battles and hooked me with his political intrigue. PHANTOM left me wanting more in the acting, story, and construction of the plot.<br />The bonus/cut scenes are interesting, but not revelatory.  I'd heard about the Greedo scene and thought that it read quite well in script form.  After seeing it on this DVD, though, I still believe that Lucas did a poor job directing his human actors and staging their scenes.<br />The effects in PHANTOM are incredible and the pod race is amazing.  However, if you don't care about the characters then you don't care how fast they are going and if they may crash!  (i.e. the &quot;Luke-and-Leia-on-speeder-bikes&quot; scene in RETURN OF THE JEDI may not have been as technically advanced as the Pod Race -- however, I actually WORRIED that they might get hit by a tree.  I can't say the same for Anakin in his pod.)<br />On a positive note:  The documentary on the 2nd disk is a lot of fun and illustrates how hard it is to bring these films to life.  The DUEL OF THE FATES music video is nice as well.  And the animatics are very interesting to watch.<br />I am a fan of George Lucas and believe that he was trying to push some bounderies on PHANTOM MENACE.  Every artist needs to grow and try new things (in his case: new technology). I also believe that he was still finding his &quot;voice&quot; after being away from directing for so long.  I have some hopes for ATTACK OF THE CLONES -- although not as high as my PHANTOM expectations.<br />I am grateful to Lucasfilm and Mr. Lucas for the DVD.  I think they've done a great joband as a long time fan of STAR WARS am appreciative.

0767827902|5.0|This movie is realy good. I happened to stumble upon it on television and i was not disappointed, but this DVD is definitely a must-have.<BR>Notes: The framing of the shots, the composition of the film, and the sound editing/music (mostly Hank Williams) are all elements that I consider outstanding in regards to this film. Ben Johnson is also excellent in his role.<BR>I hate the phrase coming-of-age, because it is a clich, but this film fits into that genre I suppose. The landscape of Anarene, TX possesses a desolate sort of beauty usually found in westerns. The plot trudges along, subordinate to the scenic beauty and composition of the film as well as the brilliant depth of characters, not unlike the film Walkabout by Nicholas Roeg or either of Terrance Malick's first two films (Badlands and Days of Heaven, though to a lesser extent). At the center of the picture is Timothy Bottoms, who plays the character Sonny. The film deals with different aspects of isolation and stagnation in its characters as those elements are inherited from the setting. This is true for all the characters - they all deal with this dilemma in different ways, however. One of the highlights of the film is the relationship between Sonny and Sam the Lion (Ben Johnson) as it is very well drawn and kindly executed. Cloris Leachman's performance as the coach's lonely wife is also noteworthy.<BR>This is one movie that succeeds because we believe in it. We believe in it because of the way the barren sparseness of the town Anarene is conveyed to us. It encourages us to feel in the most unmanipulative way. This movie's simplicity is its vitality, and vice versa. It is a film not bogged down by melodrama.<BR>On the weak side: Cybil Sheppard. I think cybil shepard is overrated, but in her defense she is presented with a fairly difficult character here.  get over your fly baby self.  luckily, in this case, age happens

LAUNDRY SERVICE offers a mix of high-energy music representative of various genres, including rock, tango, and Middle Eastern. &quot;Whenever, Wherever&quot; (&quot;Suerte&quot;) and &quot;Eyes Like Yours&quot; will make anyone get on their feet and attempt to engage in the fine art of belly dancing. Another infectious song is &quot;Objection&quot;, with its romantic tango intro that turns upbeat into a ska-inspired tune. Coupled with amazing music arrangements are solid, unpretentious lyrics that speak to the heart, as well as the mind.<br />Thank you to Shakira for putting her heart and soul into this album. B000002UB3|5.0|Abbey Road is the best album ever made. Why? Look first at the circumstances of its recording. The Beatles had all but agreed to end it after the &quot;Get Back-Let it Be&quot; fiasco. Inner turmoil and natural growth had led them to this point in their career. The story goes they phoned George Martin and said 'let's do one more like we used to'. And so they did. <BR> The instrumentation is seamless and breathtaking at points. The songs are timeless. The End suite of songs is not only powerful, but unique in recorded music. They did this in one take - unbelievable. The music on this album will be just as fresh in 2069 as it was in 1969. <BR> I've heard the working title for Abbey Road was Everest, after a favorite brand of cigarettes. Very appropriate, I think. No higher mount has been scaled in popular music to this day. This is where the progress of popular music's growth ended. What a journey, from Johnny and the Moondogs to the top of the world.

0451191153|5.0|I've read so many reviews for this book it makes me sick.  Some say its the worst book ever written while others acclaim its genius.  I would agree that Dominique's character could be seen as a little bit demeaning, and Roark is a selfish (selfish is probably not the right word because Roark never wanted money or power, he just wanted to work - his way) jerk.  But I think what Ayn Rand is trying to say is that we need people like Roark to help the human race evolve.  And it's people like Toohey who hold us back not for humanitarian reasons but for power.  <br />This book blew me away and made me take a step back and accept what Ms. Rand's point was, not necessarily agreeing with everything she says but at least accepting it and respecting it.  Also, she talks about Altruism and how (she)Roark thinks that it is holding society back, but that it's okay to give and be equal because we've been bread to do so, but there are going to be people out there who would rather give in another way, by inventions and ideas.  Roark was very clear from the beginning that he works for himself only, and his work is a gift to society.<br />I loved Toohey's rants too.  Hearing the evil badguy preach what we've all been taught since the beginning like: &quot;make man feel small and insignificant&quot;, &quot;make man associate pleasure with guilt&quot; and we all know and believe that.  The only thing I didn't like about him was that everything always went how he planned--he was too smart and manipulative to be human.<br />Love it or hate it - You should read it.  You might learn something about yourself and other people.  Her (Rand)ideas will never be outdated and in that way she'll live forever.
B00005QK3W|4.0|This CD takes several listens but my first thought was &quot;it sounds like this is something from......?&quot; Paul's styles of music are quite varied throughout this CD but after a few listens and in some cases, right away, you begin to associate many of these songs with some of his other mateial from other recordings throughout his career. The good news it's not from Red Rose Speedway or Press to Play!  On much of the CD you could tell me this was an out take from The White Album, Abbey Road or even Band on the Run, and I'd be hard pressed (not to play) to argue. She Doesn't Talk Anymore has that accoustic guitar that is so prevelent in much of the White Album while parts of Rinse The Raindrops seems like a cross between the jam of Helter Skelter and Abbey Road's I want You (she's so heavy) before segueing into a Door's rythem of L.A. Woman accented by the electric piano. As mentioned, the CD seems to borrow from a variety of differnt styles and the song Heather could easily be imagined as a melody that Pete Townshend could of used in Tommy. Basically a 4 minute instrumental with a chorus of backround &quot;ooh's and ahh's&quot; and building cresendos with Keith Moon-like drum fills throughout. Not your traditiaonal ode to love in a ballad like the title would indicate. The song Magic could easily be imagined as something from the Band on the Run sessions.  About You has echos of Oh Darling or a leftover from Run Devil Run. Overall it sounds like Paul has decided to borrow from his past.  Not a bad decission!

B00005Q66T|5.0|GHV2 is the follow up to Madonna's Immaculate Collecton, which gave us a chance to play catch up with her most vital hits, like &quot;Into The Groove&quot; and &quot;Vogue&quot;. A different Madonna is documented on the second greatest hits collection, which in itself is an accomplishment. Theres definitely growth in her songwriting (&quot;Drowned World (Substitute For Love&quot;, &quot;What It Feels Like For A Girl&quot;) and more diverse styles of production. From the infectious blues/r&amp;b of &quot;Secret&quot;, to the otherworldly Bjork/Nelee Hooper produced &quot;Bedtime Story&quot;, GHV2 doesnt leave many stones unturned, with the exception of such songs as &quot;Nothing Really Matters&quot; and the cover of Don Mclean's &quot;American Pie&quot;. There is enough to satisfy though, spanning throughout her career and conjuring many an image: the dark dominatrix dungeon rhythyms of &quot;Erotica&quot;, the beautiful and more tame &quot;Dont Cry For Me Argentina&quot;, the spiritual techno of &quot;Ray Of Light&quot; and most recently the down home on the range folk of &quot;Dont Tell Me&quot;. GHV2 is a great best of to have. Having it all in one package is easier and reminds you of how far this ever entertaining woman has come.

0316776963|5.0|About a year ago, my brother, while visting, accidently left his copy of Naked behind.  I read it, and i got hooked.  I waited forMe Talk Pretty One Dayto come out for so long, and i was not dissapointed.  It is...hilarious.  Other reviewers of this book have spoken their dissapointment because the book is not continuosly sidespliting.  It doesn't need to be.  Sedaris has the remarkable talent for bringing the humourous out of the ordinary.  He writes casualy, as if his readers already know him.  His caustic and biting writing style and pleasing and more often than not, just funny.  He pokes at everyone, his family and himself.  His stories are believable, but only just, which makes them all the more interesting.  He writes like a normal, everyday person, expressing normal everday occurences and thoughts.  His work can be sad and extremley funny at the same time.  He hit the nail right on the head in most of the stories, after reading the book, i realized that i agreed with him on most everything he wrote.  This man is amazingly persuasive and exceptionally funny.  I reccomend this book to anyone looking for a good read!

B00003CXZ1|1.0|The truth about Tomb Raider is complicated.  Even though I gave the movie only one star, the DVD does have its merits. If you're still reading this review, you're probably the type of open-minded (or obsessive/compulsive) movie watcher that actually wants to read about the DVDs high points, so here they are: <br />*  the movie has great special effects, and perfect casting of the lead character (if anyone tells you that Angelina Jolie is not the spitting image of Lara Croft in this movie, slap them...hard).  <BR>*  In a DVD, the action scenes alone may be worth the purchase for some. And one should remember that the DVD medium provides extra features, and the opportunity to skip undesireable scenes.<br />Which brings me to the reason that I gave the product only one star. The movie, in and of itself, is terrible.  Let me restate that: the movie is worse than any live-action movie of a video game I've seen (including Street Fighter), with the possbile exception of the Mario fiasco. Why?<br />**  The plot is stupid (if not for Lara's terrible judgement, there wouldn't be any drama), a number of scenes are overdeveloped, and there are really only 2 high-octane action scenes.  <BR>**  Where are the thought provoking riddles?  Where are the innovative &quot;Raiders of the Lost Ark&quot;-type tomb break-in scenes? This movie is based on a STRATEGY game...hello!!<BR>**  And for all of those people wanting to &quot;see more&quot; of Angelina Jolie, you're out of luck--the video game is more risque.<br />So, if you've got a couple of bucks burning a hole in your pocket, and you've got 20-25 minutes to kill to watch the few interesting parts of this flick, go right ahead.  Otherwise, check out the Matrix for the 15th time, or experiment with Lost In Space, or the Prince of Egypt.

B00005R2M3|4.0|This lady has a set of pipes, and she uses the full range here. Unfortunately, she doesn't flex those muscles until the second half of the disc. If this were an albumn, side 1 would never be played again, side 2 would get worn out. The first 7 songs, all in English are mostly light weight pop, with one pure disco tune, Ready For The Good Times, the first 7 songs would earn a 3 star review only because of Shakira's voice. But songs 8-13, earn 5 stars, even if 2 of the songs are duplicates from side 1 sung in Spanish. She is much more comfortable singing in Spanish and it shows on side 2, as she wraps the full range of her voice around the music. Poem To A Horse is a classic kiss off tune. For me the stand out, and FM hit is Ojos Asi, sorry, Eyes Like Yours,which is also on MTV Unplugged and Donde Estan Los Ladrones?, featuring lots of mideastern influence. Buy the CD, put some money in her pocket, and maybe she will shed the pop music suggestions from the less talented Estefans that holds this albumn back.

B00004WGC4|5.0|I have to admit that my thoughts about Fawlty Towers pre-viewer were, &quot;can anything be THAT funny?&quot; (I have rather a pessimistic nature) And the answer is yes, yes YES!<br />John Cleese is at his hysterical best (in both senses of the word)as Basil Fawlty. He is a comedian who makes a nervous breakdown the funniest thing in the world. Then there is the marvelous Prunella Scales as Cybil, his wife and (as he calls her) his little puff adder. Andrew Sachs is great as the sweet but always confused Manuel (he's from Barcelona). And of course, Cleese's real life wife at the time and writing partner, Connie Booth as Polly who runs back and forth between the bickering Fawltys and usually manages to benefit herfelf in the process.<br />The cast, as you can tell, is the reason it all works so well. For anyone who has never seen Fawlty Towers, it concerns the adventures of the staff and owners of the afore mentioned hotel. They have a talent for making a small problem into a full scale disaster until it blows up in Basil's face. And don't feel sorry for him either, he is a horrid person but a funny one.<br />My favorite episode is also &quot;The Germans&quot; with Basil suffering from a concussion ordering Polly and Manuel not to mention the war to some German guests all the while doing impressions of Hitler and other insulting things. As the German guest put it, however did they win?<br />The best tape in the set in the one with Communications Problems. It was the first one I saw and I nearly imploded from laughing so hard.<br />This is the Sistine Chapel of sitcoms (quothe Entertainment Weekly) and you definately owe it to yourself to try it out.
B00004R99U|4.0|Pocahontas II: Journey to a New World, is an above average sequel and superior to many of the other DTV Disney sqeuels. This is mainly becuase after the the first film there was still some story that needed telling.<br />While this film is gravely incorrect as far as history goes, Disney has given us a new story that shows us what happened to Pocahontas and John Smith's relationship. Pocahontas' journey to England was a terrific idea, and from that the creators were able to mine endless possibilites. All the songs are catchy, and come close to matching those of the original (surpassing some). The ending might be disappointing to some, becuase it does an injustice to the original film. But others might not mind it.<br />The Gold Collection DVD includes the Silly Symphony short &quot;Little Hiawatha&quot;, which is a wonderful little added bonus.
0761536434|5.0|Weighing in at a massive 608 pages, Steven L. Kent's THE ULTIMATE HISTORY OF VIDEO GAMES is nothing less than glorious, especially for admitted coin-op history junkies such as myself. Kent chooses to lay his foundation in Chapter 1 with the early rise of coin-op devices and the introduction of David Gottlieb's BAFFLE BALL bagatelle table in 1931. Devoting his opening pages to coin-op's roots was a wise move, he pays homage while giving the reader a greater sense of how we got here. From then on it's full tilt into the video realm. Kent utilized Leonard Herman's excellent book, PHOENIX: THE FALL &amp; RISE OF VIDEOGAMES as one of his research cornerstones, but don't let that fool you. The author logged over 500(!) interviews with the small, medium and large insiders of the video game landscape. It's an amazing feat which yields an abundance of quotes from luminaries such as Al Alcorn, Dave Theurer, Nolan Bushnell, Ray Kassar, Ed Rotberg, Maysaya Nakamura, Dave Thiel, Joel Hochberg, Dave Rosen and Ed Logg (just to name a few!). From the corporate movers and shakers to the programming geniuses, Kent leaves no voice unheard. He also weaves the intricate origination tales of giant game makers such as Sega. Few realize it was founded by Americans living in Japan and that &quot;Sega&quot; is not a Japanese word. It's an abbreviation of the original company, SErvice GAmes founded in 1952. Kent's THE ULTIMATE HISTORY OF VIDEO GAMES delves deep into the explosive home console successes and failures as well as the coin-operated arena. Even today, former CEOs marvel at the days when they could do no wrong. Just ask former Atari topper Ray Kassar who is still awestruck by the 1982 sales figures of Pac-Man cartridges. Twelve million went out the door that year, setting a retail sales record. In short, THE ULTIMATE HISTORY OF VIDEO GAMES is a book whose timing couldn't be better. With video game hobbyists and players residing throughout the world, they've come to know that the machines of their childhood are now treasured collectibles. Rest assured, there will be more and more books forthcoming about the video game phenomenon. For now, Stephen L. Kent has delivered us pixel-eyed vidiots a wondrous tome that peeks &quot;behind the screens.&quot;
B00005LC1H|5.0|If you love british comedy you'll love Fawlty Towers.  Perhaps one of the most overlooked due to its short run, but short can be sweet!  While I love the series, the DVD is not really the best.  The transfer is great with only a few bad spots, finally gets rid of the fuzz fom my videos.  The sound is average, no 5.1 but really is it needed.  Now onto the other stuff.  The commentary, as others has stated is about useless.  The extras, including outakes and montages, is lacking.  It's nice is there, but i want more outakes!!  The one shining extra are the menus.  THey are very cool.  This is still one of my favorites, and while be displayed with pride in my collection...until Are You Being Served? and Red Dwarf make it to DVD.

6304708521|4.0|As both Paul McCartney and George Harrison have stated, it was the Beatles who invented rock videos. The Fab Four created promo films for Ticket to Ride, Paperback Writer, Rain, Strawberry Fields and Penny Lane prior to the release of &quot;Magical Mystery Tour&quot; in 1967. It is the video performances of Blue Jay Way, I Am the Walrus, Your Mother Should Know, etc. which are, without a doubt, the highlight of &quot;Mystery Tour&quot;. Admittedly, the movie is amateurish; lacking in plot and void of any sensibility. Taken as a film per se, &quot;Magical Mystery Tour&quot; would rate 1-star. However, taken as a compilation of videos, the film greatly succeeds. (I simply skip the nonsensical parts and head straight for the musical performances.) The music is, of course, absolutely impeccable and the videos are so much more engaging than current MTV fare. In fact, the clip for I Am the Walrus-- with its dancing &quot;eggmen&quot;-- may just be the coolest, most off-beat song promo ever filmed. The spot for Fool on the Hill --with Paul gazing high atop the Pyrennes-- is absolutely beautiful and quite befitting of that elegant song. Also, you just gotta love that silly wizard garb the guys break out for their performance of the title song. On the downside, the DVD itself is subpar. The picture, in dire need of remastering, is inexcusably grainy. Quite frankly, the film looks like a cheap VHS transfer. So why 4-stars for a plotless movie wrapped in a lousy DVD presentation? One word: MUSIC! More specifically, great Beatle music. That is the saving grace of &quot;Magical Mystery Tour&quot;.

But they are in fact being haunted a ghost who possibly is a danger. I'm not so uptight that I'll deny this is an alright episode. But the plot is not really up to Scooby's usual levels.
