B00005Q66T|5.0|First of all, I have to admit that my opinions might seem anything but objective. Those close to me know that I have a bit of a bias in Madonna's favor, but that's because She has never given me reason NOT to...and GHV2, her first &quot;greatest hits&quot; compilation since 1990's phenomenally successful (and simply phenomenal) The Immaculate Collection, is proof of her endless superiority. With that having been said, I feel truly blessed to be among the first people to share with the world my thoughts on the year's best record, &quot;GHV2&quot;. <br />The 1990s gave Madonna a slew of Top 10 singles and seven multi-platinum records, yet many viewed it as a less successful period for her than her 1980s heyday. That's merely because her work was less mainstream, and much more progressive; it's no wonder that the Erotica album took years before it was reappraised as one of her finest works. It was also the decade in which Madonna's non-musical ventures earned more media attention than her music: the banned videos, the successful films, the not-so-successful films, the Sex book, her pregnancy, etc. But while the media was busy misinterpreting every move Madonna made, and looking for any opportunity to pronounce her as \\"over\\" (a groundless accusation fired from many \\"reputable\\" publications), she was busy cranking out the best music of her career. Madonna is one of the few 20th century performers to avoid peaking early, and instead to continue outdoing herself; her voice improved with age, her style was constantly changing, and each subsequent album outdid the last one. <br />Flash forward to 2001. With Madonna at yet another one of her \\"peaks\\" following the hugely successful Drowned World Tour, mainstream audiences are now getting the chance to reevaluate Madonna's most stellar musical accomplishments in the form of GHV2. And for anyone who quips that infamous \\"she was better in the 80s\\" mantra, I urge you to listen to this album just once. One listen to GHV2 and memories of the timeless Immaculate Collection all but disappear. Like TIC, this is one of Madonna's most incessantly listenable albums; pop this into your stereo at your next party, and you will have no need to skip tracks or switch discs. Also like TIC, it traces Madonna's evolution, only this time the evolution is more personal than musical. The 90s offered fans Madonna's most introspective music (her wonderful 80s work was slightly more ambiguous) and the journey the listener takes visits every stop in Madonna's life and career over the past ten years: the anger, frustration, and sorrow of Erotica; the somber and contemplative outlook of Bedtime Stories; the personal and artistic triumph of Evita; the emotional and spiritual understanding of Ray of Light; and the innovative euphoria of Music. <br />Like all fans, I was initially hoping for some bonus tracks or new mixes of Madonna's classics, but Madonna truly knows best, because there's nothing about this collection that warrants alteration. I might have liked more tracks from Erotica to be included, but that is an album which works best as a whole rather than being divided into singles. And while the exclusion of ballads like \\"This Used to be My Playground\\" and \\"I'll Remember\\" is noticeable, it should encourage listeners to pick up her outstanding 1995 ballad-only collection, Something to Remember. <br />Madonna's success and influence continues to astonish all of us, from the most passionate fans to the most jaded critics. How many artists see fit to release a \\"greatest hits\\" collection every ten years? How many artists are lucky enough to have ANY hits every ten years? Madonna is truly unprecedented, and as many have said before, her show is far from over. Imitators and naysayers have come and gone, and many more will come and go in the years ahead. In the meantime, we can all sit back and appreciate all that she has done for the world of art and entertainment. Madonna herself has often noted that \\"the music is all but forgotten\\" in the cultural whirlwind that is her life, and now it's time for us to remember. GHV2 contains fifteen songs, any one of which could have made a lesser artist's entire career. Yet for Madonna, each served merely as a stepping stone into the future, and her path is as endlessly delectable as it is artistically rich.<br />Simply put, GHV2 is perfect. It's also priceless, and a wonderful reminder of how lucky we are to be sharing a lifetime with the greatest artist and greatest entertainer of them all.<br />Thank you Madonna....for everything.
1583762027|5.0|We all have our frogs - important tasks that we've put off for whatever reason. The key to success is to eat your frogs quickly, completely and with focused determination. So says Brian Tracy, the master of hard-nosed time management. You'll find no touchy-feely personal development pabulum here. The message of this book: Action leads to accomplishment. With that simple rule in mind, Tracy rolls out tools and techniques that will get you off your backside and into motion. We [...], while uneager to take up noshing on amphibians (well, maybe just the legs, in plenty of garlic butter), strongly recommend this book to anyone caught in the swamp of procrastination.

6300270424|3.0|Filming of this concert at Madison Square Garden took place at the end of July 1973 and the end of the 1973 tour year for Led Zeppelin&#8212;and it shows in almost every performance.  As a rabid Zeppelin fan who owns many live Zeppelin concert recordings (including several from 1973), I can assure you that what you hear in this video is not the Zeppelin you would hear in March or May of that year, which were far better shows.  In those months, Zeppelin is fresh and energized and they often left your out of breath.  Here in this concert footage&#8212;with bits and pieces that were taken from each of the three shows&#8212;Page shows some signs of being spent from the long touring year and Robert's voice is just horrid in some spots.  Both freely admit that these concerts were not their best effort and both have often bemoaned both the quality of the footage and the quality of play.  Lot of the blame could be put on the awful editing job which is evident throughout the film to fit three days of the best music into one supposed concert night (notice how their clothes change from scene to scene?).  Additionally, there are several concert footage scenes that were \\"re-filmed\\" in a reconstructed studio set of the concert stage (for proof, look at Plant's teeth.  In one shot, they'll be crooked, in other shots perfectly straight.  Why?  Because he had his teeth fixed after 1973 and the \\"re-filming\\" captured that).  But of all the many cuts found strewn throughout the film, the most criminal cut occurs in \\"Whole Lotta Love\\" right before the Theramin section&#8212;it's amazing someone could have gotten away with that one.  There are several in \\"Dazed and Confused\\", too, that rank up there in the list of poor edits.  Even after Page's solo in \\"Stairway to Heaven\\" (perhaps his finest in that touring year), the film cuts to the previous night because Plant liked the way he sounded that night instead.  If you listen closely, this cut completely unbalances the tempo of the song.  Lastly, watch Jones very closely after the end of \\"Whole Lotta Love\\".  He takes his bass guitar off twice.  It's that kind of mediocre production that plagues this entire film.<br />But even with all the complaints, I still love this film.  It actually was the reason why I became the Zeppelin fan I am today.  I watched it one weekend in 1986, and I have been addicted to Zeppelin ever since.  As so many other reviewers have said here, even a relatively weak Zeppelin performance is worth its wait in gold.  The boys still pull off a lot of exciting moments in these songs, most noticeably in TSRTS, DAC, NQ, and SIBLY.  So despite my reservations about the film itself, I still would recommend it to Zeppelin and non-Zeppelin fan alike.  Jimmy was a true guitar sorcerer in those days, and Jones & Bonham were simply gigantic from one night to the next&#8212;the best rhythm section ever in the history of rock bands.  No other live band then and now can match these guys in talent.

B00000253N|5.0|Bob Dylan's 1975 classic, Blood On the Tracks, competes only with Fleetwood Mac's Rumours as the greatest break-up album of all-time and, as stunning as Rumours is, not even its heartfelt sentiments can compete with the deeply personal album rock's leading songwriter recorded after divorcing his wife, Sara, in 1974. For Blood on the Tracks, Dylan abandoned the jamrock of his recent work with the Band, donned a simple acoustic guitar and meditated on his recent tribulations. What he produced is astounding. Perhaps only when confronting subject matter as emotionally complex as divorce do fans see what an able songwriter Dylan truly is. The ten masterpieces of Blood on the Tracks, be them love songs; hate songs; break-up songs; apology songs or other, are some of the most mature, affecting and insightful tracks ever recorded about relationships. Dylan's thoughtfulness and ingenuity tower over typical rock music about love and loss. Thousands of fine love songs have been crafted but no hate song matches the cleverness, power and downright cruelty of \\"Idiot Wind.\\" \\"If You See Her Say Hello\\" is one of the most achingly heartfelt, naked expressions of regret I have ever encountered. \\"You`re Gonna Make Me Lonesome When You Go\\" and \\"Buckets of Rain\\" are winsome and heartening expressions about letting go. The remarkable, happy-go-lucky ballad, \\"Tangled Up in Blue\\" makes life seem like an exciting venture like no other tune. Each song is pleasingly melodic, deeply reflective and lyrically brilliant. I can not recommend this album more highly. No album in the rock cannon is quite as clever, tuneful and moving as Blood On the Tracks.
B00005QXXO|4.0|What can I say?  This live cd is really great.  You get the true experience of listening to a Radiohead concert.  These tracks are not just the studio versions played live. No!  These are tracks with new energy, new arragements, and at times new instrumentation.  For example &quot;National Anthem&quot; has a new intro with Thom doing a crazed human-beatbox vocal which add a great new dynamic to the song, not to mention the bassline being really fuzzy, making for the ultimate groove.  On &quot;idioteque&quot;, Phil helps out on acoustic drums to complement that techno beat.  Finally on &quot;like spinning plates&quot;, instead of the weird/warped/backward studio version, here it is a piano piece with synth strings swooshing in and out with the rest of the band warping Thom's vocals.<BR>  So, these songs are bigger and def. better than their studio versions.  A def. must for those wanting the definitive radiohead live as well and cool versions of their studio favorites.  All the songs were recorded in Oxford, Oslo, Berlin, and Vaison La Romaine.<br />ps<BR>you also get &quot;true love waits&quot;, thom and acoustic guitar, a song they have played for years but never officially released!
B000002I2M|4.0|In the final days of their career, the Doors got back to their roots. Along with accenting the rollicking blues riffs and cryptic poetry that are the basics of their music, that process consisted of returning to their hometown of Los Angeles. The influence of that setting permeates through 1971's L.A. Woman. Los Angeles is, of coarse, &quot;the city of night&quot; and a brooding, sinister dusk looms over most of L.A. Woman. The title epic and the cover of John Lee Hooker's &quot;Crawling King Snake&quot; (made distinctly phallic by its slow, slinky rhythm and leadsinger, Jim Morrison's husky tone) are as forebodingly sexual as the blues can get. &quot;Riders on the Storm,&quot; a dusty, whispering song about a serial killer, is even creepier than the band's notorious epic, &quot;The End.&quot; &quot;Been Down So Long&quot; is an excellent, gritty, prison-encased blues rocker. All songs on L.A. Woman are enhanced by Morrison's gruff, brawny vocals and the band's funky arrangements both sounding more forceful and confident than every before. The Doors were certainly in their element here. L.A. Woman is a magnificently decadent album.

B000003S0K|4.0|Influence from both protopunk band, the Velvet Underground and minimalist composer, LaMonte Young, is apparent on sonic experimentalist, Brian Eno's 1973 solo debut, Here Come the Warm Jets. The album is a schizophrenic soup of the avant-garde. Sometimes blistering hard rock centered around layers of distorted guitars bursts out (\\"Blank Frank,\\" \\"Needles in the Camel's Eye\\"), sometimes an achingly, beautiful composition erupts (\\"On Some Faraway Beach,\\" the title track) and sometimes a quirky, glamrock oddity is provided (\\"Dead Finks Don't Talk\\" \\"The Paw Paw Negro Blowtorch,\\" a song about a sex toy featuring a hilarious, squeaking, mechanical keyboard solo). No matter where he wanders, Brian Eno does little wrong on this album. Few musicians can pool so many extremes and oddities into such an infectious, cohesive mix as well as Eno.

B0000024SI|5.0|Mixing the electric blues sound of Muddy Waters and Sonny Boy Williamson and the surreal, beatnik lyricism of Allen Ginsberg and William S. Burroughs with his own rapid-fire rhymes and croaky, yet striking, vocals, Bob Dylan shaped a flawless, stark, dry version of the blues for 1965's Highway 61 Revisited. The characters in Dylan's songs are lonely, witty and severely nervous. The surreal word frenzies of tracks like \\"Tombstone Blues,\\" the title song and the shaky \\"It Takes a Lot to Laugh, It Takes a Train to Cry\\" are funhouse mirrors reflecting the trying era in which they were recorded. The murky sound and the bizarre wordplay are perfect for this awesome magnum opus of uncertainty, antipathy and fright.

B000002J03|4.0|After their rough, shrieking debut, Led Zeppelin tightened up their potent, bluesy sound with 1969's Led Zeppelin II. With the exception of the rambling \\"Lemon Song,\\" Zeppelin II features succinct riff rock. They do not loose much of their ardor (Listen to hypercharged \\"Whole Lotta Love\\" for proof). The rough edges are merely smoothed out. Instead of the moaning, spiraling epics of their self-entitled debut (\\"Babe I'm Gonna Leave You,\\" \\"Dazed and Confused,\\" \\"I Can't Quit You Babe,\\") Led Zeppelin II presents the Chuck Berry-ish bop of \\"Heartbreaker,\\" \\"Living Loving Maid (She's Just a Woman)\\" and \\"Ramble On\\" and neatly trimmed tumblers like \\"What Is and What Should Never Be\\" and \\"Moby Dick.\\" The earsplitting impact of their first album is lost, but Led Zeppelin II is still a winner. The melodic, succinct tunes are memorable, catchy and still pretty darned rocking. Their second album features the seminal British hard rock band cutting a fine, fiery batch of tighter tunes.

B000002UA2|4.0|1972's Obscured by Clouds is the most unjustly overlooked album in Pink Floyd's catalogue. Its instrumentals, the title track; \\"When You're In;\\" \\"Absolutely Curtains\\" and especially \\"Mudmen,\\" are some of the finest wavy, lavalamp psychedelica I have ever heard. \\"Childhood's End;\\" \\"Free Four\\" (the first song in which Roger Waters, deals with the death of his father in WW2) and \\"Stay,\\" (sung seamlessly in keyboardist, Richard Wright's dry hum) feature on a new, humanistic approach to the band's songwriting. The clear, trancelike sound and down-to-earth subject matter are fine precursors to the style employed on Floyd's legendary works, Dark Side of the Moon and Wish You Were Here. If you love those albums, Obscured by Clouds is certainly well worth considering.

B00005QK3W|4.0|Another splendid effort from Paul.  Some rockers, some charming love songs, some experimental forays, some driving bass playing, and some great vocals from rock's best melodic voice.  Lonely Road is a strong opener reminiscent of World Tonight from Flaming Pie.  From A Lover To A Friend is instantly likeable and grows on you.  She's Given Up Talking - a weaker effort - weak melody and lyrics.  Sometimes Paul seems to try too hard to be clever or profound and it just ends up being weird!  The title track has a fascinating chord progression and catchy beat and tune which make up for the 12345...   678910 lyric!  I Do is a classic McCartney love song, easy to relate to and sing along to.  Tiny Bubble is infectious with a cool progression which sounds a bit like &quot;Piggies&quot; (a GH song). Magic - nice track...  Your Way - has that nice country guitar sound that McCartney occasionally uses with good humour - very likeable song.  Spinning on an Axis - oops!  &quot;It's the season of the culture bat&quot; as lyric doesn't help this song either!  &quot;Heather&quot; is a lovely tune.  Slightly odd but heartfelt lyrics. &quot;Loving Flame&quot; has a great element of passion.  &quot;Riding into Jaipur&quot; uses Indian instruments and tonality very effectively.  A nice contrast within the album.  The last track, Rinse the Raindrops is a bit long but has some great improvising.  Then comes the bonus track, Freedom, live from the NY concert.  Great tune, and what a great voice at the tender age of 59!  <BR>     The album would be helped by dropping a couple of tracks as suggested above (16 songs including the bonus track).  I think that some of McCartney's albums would have been better received by critics if he had only been to identify an embarrassing track of two and leave them off! A catchy single a la Hope of Deliverance from Off the Ground or Young Boy from Flaming Pie would have been welcome too.  <BR>    Anyway, as a professional musician who has all of McCartney's studio albums, I am certainly pleased with Driving Rain. While it's not one of the top level McCartney albums like Tug of War, Band on the Run, Flaming Pie or Flowers in the Dirt, it's not far behind either.

B00005AQGH|5.0|The last real album from Tupac Shakur is without doubt the finest example of real rap music in existence. Released less than two months after his &quot;death&quot; in Las Vegas drive-by shooting it finds him at the top of his form. Every track is so deep multiple listens will still not discover every hidden meaning and lyric that this album has to offer. The album begins with a mock report on the album's release and this leads into the opening track Bomb First featuring EDI &amp; Young Noble from the Outlawz, on this track 'Pac rips into his enemies and just destroys them. However, dissing is not the main focus and 'Pac only twice more goes for enemies, dismissing Dr. Dre on Toss It Up and mentioning everyone who crossed him on Against All Odds. The deep, mysterious tracks begin with Hail Mary, again featuring the Outlawz (this time Young Noble &amp; Kastro), an infamous hook and killer verses, just a classic cut. <BR>The only real party track follows, Toss It Up featuring K-Ci &amp; Jo-Jo, Danny Boy and Aaron Hall. &quot;To Live &amp; Die In LA&quot; is a laid back, relaxed track which just can't help giving you the feeling of lounging in LA watching the day go by. Next &quot;Blasphemy&quot; as deep and mysterious as you will get, Prince Ital Joe's hook, the slightly altered Lord's prayer and chilling lyrics which just compel you to listen. &quot;Life Of An Outlaw&quot; as you might guess features the Outlawz (EDI, Napoleon, Kastro &amp; Noble) and is one of the most uptempo, in-your-face tracks on the album. &quot;Just Like Daddy&quot; is the usual track on a 2Pac album dedicated to women, again with the Outlawz (EDI, Kastro, Noble &amp; Kadafi's lone appearance), a great feeling track and possibly the most accessible.<BR>The standout cut is &quot;Krazy&quot; featuring LBC rapper Bad Azz, the most thugged-out beat and lyrics ever, you just wanna roll up the windows and just ride around the city. &quot;White Man'z World&quot; is a brilliantly emotional song charting his mistakes and regrets living in a &quot;white man's world&quot; and also features clips of Malcolm X &amp; Martin Luther King Jr. In &quot;Me &amp; My Girlfriend&quot; 'Pac's gun is his girl and he uses his lyrics well to get this across. &quot;Hold Ya Head&quot; is to me an updated version of &quot;Keep Ya Head Up&quot; this time open to men and women alike and even surpasses the original. The album finishes with &quot;Against All Odds&quot; aimed at all of 'Pac enemies (note the omission of BIG, did 'Pac know something we didn't??) and finishes, some would say aptly with a collection of gunshots.<BR>The first time I heard this album was five years ago (Nov. 96) and still now I listen to it a lot, nothing since then has or probably will eclipse &quot;The 7 Day Theory&quot;, the best and most intriguing piece of music ever to be compiled.

B00005QK3W|3.0|Thanks in part to the Concert for New York, this has to be one of the most anticipated albums in Paul's career. As usual, expectations are high, especially in light of the phenomenal, Grammy nominated work found on &quot;Flaming Pie&quot;.  My first words of advice to anyone out there interested in &quot;Driving Rain&quot;: &quot;Flaming Pie 2&quot; it ain't.<br />Paul bravely takes on a modern, semi-alternative sound on this album, and at times it doesn't fit. But alas, he is a guy who's been in the business for some 30 odd years, so it's only natural that he tries to go a different, hipper route (a la Eric Clapton on &quot;Pilgrim&quot;). The album starts off with &quot;Lonely Road&quot; and &quot;From a Lover to a Friend&quot;, two meloncholy songs with  optimistic messages and catchy choruses. &quot;She's Given Up Talking&quot; has a dark, alternative feel to it and comes off as a pleasant surprise. &quot;Driving Rain&quot; is weak, plain and simple. Again, the music is different, but the lyrics are weak.....&quot;Bip Bop Bam&quot; weak.&quot;I Do&quot; and &quot;Tiny Bubble&quot; are bright and pleasant songs, with the latter tune achieving a jumpy pop feel. &quot;Magic&quot; is the ode to  Linda; an ok song, a bit overdone. &quot;Your Way&quot; is another gentle Paul love song with shades of some of George Harrison's work on &quot;All Things Must Pass&quot;. &quot;Spinning on an Axis&quot; and &quot;About You&quot; are the &quot;rockers&quot; of the album, which isn't saying a whole lot.<br />&quot;Heather&quot; is a mostly instrumental song, with a few utterly daft lyrics. &quot;Your Loving Flame&quot; is a standout, tried and true Macca track, complete with Beatlesque backing vocals. &quot;Back in the Sunshine&quot; feels tired after the first few lyrics. Ah, the lyrics. I am saddened to say this, but I think Sir Paul has finally hit a brick wall in his writing.  Don't get me wrong, there are several tracks on here that stand up lyrically with most of his solo efforts; but as a whole, he generalizes most of the songs and seems to have lost that magic touch he had just a few years ago.<br />We all know this album is about two things: Linda, and Heather. Missing Linda, and cherishing the vitality, optimisim and freshness of his relationship with Heather. It's not that there's anything wrong with having a specific inspiration for an album because it's worked for him in the past. However, in the case of &quot;Driving Rain&quot;, the intial listen will leave you with the realization that at least 7 of the songs on the album are  about the same thing, said in the same way. <br />Paul is either going to get ripped for trying a modern sound, or enjoy the praise both Bob Dylan and Clapton achieved with their contemporary releases just a few years ago.  I for one don't criticize Paul for attempting to update himself ; half the time it actually works. But I have to point out what can only be described as disapointment in the lyrics found in these songs....c'mon Paul, &quot;12345, let's go for a drive&quot;? You CAN do better. One final note: stealing the stomp-and-clap thing off &quot;Give Peace a Chance&quot; for &quot;Freedom&quot;? Not very original...but then again, neither are the lyrics.

B00003CWL6|1.0|Of course this review will be the small voice of dissent in a sea of praise, but I'm writing for the few who will listen. Okay so this movie was making a statement about what is wrong with America today, it's supposed to deal with the superficiality of the American suburbs, the hypocrisy of family today, blah blah blah. You get all of that within the first 5 minutes of the movie. The rest of it is all rose petals falling and an excuse pass off nudity as &quot;art&quot;. At no point in this movie was it necessary to for us to see Mena Suvari's breasts. They were totally completely superfluous to the movie. But, hey, this movie is an &quot;artistic masterpiece&quot; so, therefore some nudity is required. Every single scene in this movie was the director screaming from the rooftops: &quot;look at me, I'm making an artistic movie and since many of us aspire to be 'intellectual', i.e. pretentious, we'll praise it because it's 'different' &quot;. What was the point of this movie? Was he trying to get across a message that something is wrong with American society today? If so, he could have done it without Mena Suvari's breasts, the rose petals, and of course the most &quot;beautiful scene in the whole movie&quot; - I refer of course that oh-so-profound scene where the the marijuana-peddling voyeur neighbour says that the plastic bag flowing in the wind was so beautiful. Gosh, that statement had me almost emptying my stomach in the wrong way. Ok, I'll admit that at certain points in the movie, I had to laugh out loud, there was definitely some good humour, but most of this movie, was a useless, senseless, pretentious waste of film. So the director wanted to make the statement that something was wrong with society today. Tell me something I don't know. Look for the beauty in everyday life? Sure, but it wasn't anywhere in the movie. Compare this to another movie which wanted to bring home the tragedy of the twisted world we live in - Life is Beautiful. The director of that movie didn't need to show breasts, didn't even need to use curse words and what little violence there was was implied. Yet it brings home to all of us, how cruel and beautiful and complex human beings are. Another good movie which released around the same time - Fight Club. Also a very brilliantly done movie. The best way to get a social message across is subtlety. This movie was as subtle as sledgehammer. All this movie does is take the worst possible in all of us and put it onscreen. Either way, there was no reason for anybody to see Mena Suvari's breasts. Of course this review will just be voted least helpful, but hey, somebody had to be brave enough to criticize this movie.

B000002GF8|5.0|It's hard to believe, even over a decade later, that this was the last album from The Police.  Most bands release albums that build on each other, reach an artistic (not necessarily a commercial) peak, and then decline.  Not so this band.  They made it to their peak, and then that was it as far as new material.  This is an album no fan of '80s music should be without.  It's also one of those albums that makes me appreciate the CD format, because I long ago wore out my casette copy.  Luckily, I can listen to this CD for years to come and the sound will be just as awesome every time.  <br />The lion's share of the songwriting of this album was done by Sting, who is an absolute virtuoso in creating rhymes.  This is showcased on the first track, Synchronicity I.  It's the perfect choice to lead off the album.  It and its companion piece, Synchronicity II, form an interesting contrast.  SI is fairly light, and SII is extremely dark and disturbing.  Both songs, however, are masterpieces of lyrical composition.  SII draws a disturbing comparison between a harried corporate drone, doing a slow burn as he fights traffic on his way home after a mind-numbing workday, and a monster emerging from the shore of a certain &quot;dark Scottish lake&quot;.  <br />This album contains many of the songs that the Police are now remembered for, 15+ years after their last album, including the classics King of Pain and Wrapped Around Your Finger.  The most under-appreciated song in the album is the intruiging Tea in the Sahara, and Murder by Numbers is laugh-out-loud hilarious.  But the absolute best song on there (and maybe the best song produced by the Police ever) is Every Breath You Take.  I remember when this song first came out in 1983.  For several months, it had an iron grip on the Number 1 position on the charts.  What seems at first listen to be a beautiful love song is actually a sinister song about possesiveness and jealousy.  Only Sting can produce stuff like that.  <br />The two songs written by the rest of the band, Mother and Miss Gradenko, are both decent, but not as good as Sting's work.  Mother is interesting because of its annoying, grating melody.  But the thing is, it's SUPPOSED to annoy you, given the song's subject matter.  I didn't really appreciate this song when the album first came out, but now, as an adult out on my own, it takes on a whole new significance.<br />Overall, this is an excellent CD, especially the remastered version.  This is an album that no fan of 80s music should be without.  The Police were a stand-out act in an era full of excellent music.  Part of me wishes they were still together, especially given the high quality of Sting's solo work, and part of me is glad they chose to go out on top.

0767836324|2.0|Steven Spielberg is arguably the most talented and most succesful movie Director ever. I love most of his films to varying degrees. He is an incredible talent but I'm sorry I, like Siskel and Ebert before me (and many other people), just don't like this movie. It's not that it's awful, it's just not very good and generally forgettable I'm afraid to say. Okay it's got a stellar cast (Dustin Hoffman, Robin Williams, Julia Roberts and Bob Hoskins etc.) but it really fails to catch the imagination of either kids or adults (and even Spielberg reportedly conceded this).<br />You'd have to ask whether it was a good idea in the first instance to make Peter Pan an adult in what is essentially a kid's story in this unfortunate adaptation of the classic JM Barrie tale, that just doesn't work. What was wrong with the original story that they had to change it? if it aint broke then don't try to fix it is the old addage that Spielberg should have heeded but on top of this the film is even, dare I say it, technically ropey. I mean is it just me or do the movie sets look like movie sets and isn't the script amazingly poor by the great maestro's standards? The cast can't save it either, they're all fine but essentially wasted and is it any coincidence that this movie went 40 days over its 76 day shooting schedule, during a particularly turbulent time in Julia Roberts life (does anyone remember Kiefer Sutherland?). Don't get me wrong I'm not blaming Ms Roberts for the movies failure. It wasn't her fault and I greatly admire her work but it's symptomatic of a movie that just doen't work and it goes to show you that even the greatest occasionally get it all wrong...( and so there's hope for us mere mortals yet)!

B00005QGAV|5.0|MJ, largely aided and abetted by New Jack Swing King Teddy Riley really produced a great album here!<br />Originally released in two LP package, the first half (written in main by Teddy Riley) is so funky it hurts.<br />&quot;Jam&quot; is a real stomper of a tune and is followed by my personal album favourite, &quot;Why You Wanna Trip On Me&quot;. This song although simple lyrically has such great vocal layering, Princely funk guitar and hard beats. It's very defiant, almost angry and dark as a large amount of this album proves to be.<br />This similar uptempo New Jack vibe continues through the great single &quot;In The Closet&quot; and &quot;She Drives Me Wild&quot;. <br />&quot;Remember The Time&quot; (A massive hit) is the most commercial of the upbeat material but is excellent with it and contains very addictive melodic refrains.<br />&quot;Can't Let Her Get Away&quot; brings to a close the uniformly, superb, themed material before the vibe changes greatly...<br />&quot;Heal The World&quot; while too sickly for some is a well conceived anthemic ballad and sincere enough to merit musical acclaim (Unlike those it spawned: &quot;Childhood&quot;, &quot;Litle Suzie&quot; and some of the &quot;Invincible&quot; ballads such as &quot;Lost Children&quot; one could argue). Criticise if you will but back in 1991 it was done profficiently and is ultimately well intentioned.<br />&quot;Black &amp; White&quot; is another commercial (What else do you want from &quot;The King Of Pop&quot;?) song, which bar the embarassing Macaulay Culkin intro and throwaway rap is a groovy, addictive call for racial unity.<br />It then get's much darker with the brooding, dark &quot;Who Is It?&quot; and unoffical Dirty Diana Pt 2, &quot;Give In To Me&quot;. Both are excellent and it just goes to show what a master of all trades MJ at his peak can be.<br />&quot;Will You Be There&quot; is a real highlight. After an operatic intro the song segues into a rousing gospel number. MJ's pleading vocals are truly on top form here.<br />&quot;Keep The Faith&quot; goes to lift the dark mood with it's inspiring lyrics and mid tempo funk instrumentation on the chorus.<br />&quot;Gone Too Soon&quot; is a peaceful little tune with string accompaniment. It's good enough but is arguably amongst the weakest on the LP and perhaps the album as a whole whould have benefited from a shorter length (It's 77 minutes long!) with this track edited off for B-Side duties.<br />The final joint &quot;Dangerous&quot; takes us back to the opening New Jack Swing material and is equally as consistent as the other Teddy Riley songs. A worthy title track and great way to close out the album.<br />&quot;Dangerous&quot; (The album) proved an exciting evolution for Michael. Teddy Riley really laced him with top class material here and broke him into the 90s with ease. The album is universally superb with few (if any) weak moments and this over 14 tracks and 77 minutes! It ranks comfortably alongside his previous three legendary Epic albums and that says a lot.<br />This new re-mastered format can only add to the experience when the original CD album sounds great anyway.
B00004XQ83|5.0|this is THE movie soundtrack of the new millenium. though i could not normally stand the type of music on this cd, they picked the best songs from the genre, and made it so that essentially anyone can own and love it.
B0000026WD|5.0|MJ, largely aided and abetted by New Jack Swing King Teddy Riley really produced a great album here!<br />Originally released in two LP package, the first half (written in main by Teddy Riley) is so funky it hurts.<br />&quot;Jam&quot; is a real stomper of a tune and is followed by my personal album favourite, &quot;Why You Wanna Trip On Me&quot;. This song although simple lyrically has such great vocal layering, Princely funk guitar and hard beats. It's very defiant, almost angry and dark as a large amount of this album proves to be.<br />This similar uptempo New Jack vibe continues through the great single &quot;In The Closet&quot; and &quot;She Drives Me Wild&quot;. <br />&quot;Remember The Time&quot; (A massive hit) is the most commercial of the upbeat material but is excellent with it and contains very addictive melodic refrains.<br />&quot;Can't Let Her Get Away&quot; brings to a close the uniformly superb themed material before the vibe changes greatly...<br />&quot;Heal The World&quot; while too sickly for some is a well conceived anthemic ballad and sincere enough to merit musical acclaim (Unlike those it spawned: &quot;Childhood&quot;, &quot;Litle Suzie&quot; and some of the &quot;Invincible&quot; ballads such as &quot;Lost Children&quot; one could argue). Criticise if you will but back in 1991 it was done profficiently and is ultimately well intentioned.<br />&quot;Black &amp; White&quot; is another commercial (What else do you want from &quot;The King Of Pop&quot;?) song, which bar the embarassing Macaulay Culkin intro and throwaway rap is a groovy, addictive call for racial unity.<br />It then get's much darker with the brooding, dark &quot;Who Is It?&quot; and unoffical Dirty Diana Pt 2, &quot;Give In To Me&quot;. Both are excellent and it just goes to show what a master of all trades MJ at his peak can be.<br />&quot;Will You Be There&quot; is a real highlight. After an operatic intro the song segues into a rousing gospel number. MJ's pleading vocalsare truly on top form here.<br />&quot;Keep The Faith&quot; goes to lift the dark mood with it's inspiring lyrics and mid tempo funk instrumentation on the chorus.<br />&quot;Gone Too Soon&quot; is a peaceful little tune with string accompaniment. It's good enough but is arguably amongst the weakest on the LP and perhaps the album as a whole whould have benefited from a shorter length (It's 77 minutes long!) with this track edited off for B-Side duties.<br />The final joint &quot;Dangerous&quot; takes us back to the opening New Jack Swing material and is equally as consistent as the other Teddy Riley songs. A worthy title track and great way to close out the album.<br />&quot;Dangerous&quot; (The album) proved an exciting evolution for Michael. Teddy Riley really laced him with top class material here and broke him into the 90s with ease. The album is universally superb with few (if any) weak moments and this over 14 tracks and 77 minutes! It ranks comfortably alongside his previous three legendary Epic albums and that says a lot.

B0000024Z7|5.0|Jazz ideas had already been creeping into Santana's music on tracks like &quot;Incident at Neshabur&quot; and &quot;Toussaint L'Overture&quot;, but Caravanserai boldly moved deep into jazz-rock territory.  The upbeat and catchy Latin rock of the band's first 3 albums was replaced by a more meditative, abstract and instrumentally-focused style influenced by Miles Davis's early electric bands and Chick Corea's Return to Forever.<br />  Most of the band's original members are still here (Gregg Rolie, Mike Shrieve, Chepito Areas) but their roles have changed dramatically.  Mike Shrieve suddenly steps up in the compositional department and his drumming really improves.  Check out his Elvin Jones-isms on &quot;Waves Within&quot;.  Gregg Rolie sticks to keyboards (lots of electric piano) and the remaining vocals are pleasantly inconsequential.  Guests make a big difference -- Tom Rutley's acoustic bass is a nice touch on many of the tunes, and future keyboardist Tom Coster makes his first appearance on a Santana album.  Carlos and Neil Schon play off each other really well.  The tunes range all over the map, from the epic &quot;Every Step of the Way&quot; (the guitar riff that ends the intro is awesome) to serious funk (&quot;Look Up&quot;) to percussion duets (&quot;Future Primitive&quot;).<br />  The influence of Latin music is still here in a big way with the gentle Jobim cover &quot;Stone Flower&quot; and the grooving instrumental &quot;La Fuente del Ritmo&quot;, but people expecting the Classic Santana will be disappointed.  Nevertheless this is one of Santana's best albums, right up there with Abraxas; whereas their later jazz-rock efforts were often mixed bags, it works here in a big way.

It's pure image.  Maybe someday the Maggots will grow up and listen to something a bit more diverse.  I've always liked the hard stuff, but one must be able to make a differentiation between a good metal/hardcore band and one that's just ugly and loud.  Sure, it frightens and pisses off the parents, but look what happened to Marilyn Manson(or what didn't happen to MM); the guy's almost mainstream now(didn't I hear a cover of &quot;Tainted Love&quot; on the radio yesterday?).  I guess this stuff is for the midwestern kids who have no city to go to to see a real hardcore band.  Go to NY, DC, LA, Cleveland, Baltimore and check out Next Step Up, Integrity, Darkside, Clutch, or at least visit Victory Records.  Just as hard(or even harder) as Slipknot or anyone else, but with an actual social agenda instead of vomit and feces.

B000002AS1|5.0|I don't know what it is about Alan Silvestri, but his scores have the ability to stir up emotions in me that no other artist can do.  Some of my favorite soundtracks of all time are works that he has done - the &quot;Back to the Future&quot; trilogy, &quot;Cast Away&quot; and the &quot;Father of the Bride&quot; movies.  &quot;Forrest Gump,&quot; for all intents and purposes, is some of his best work ever.<br />None of the songs are very long (the entire CD is not much longer than a half-hour), but that doesn't mean they aren't beautiful.  A lot of tracks on the CD are these meek little songs that act like they are afraid to bloom.  Others are full of life, overflowing with vibrancy.  Both represent the character of Forrest, as well as the events and people in his life, extremely well.<br />About the only gripe I have with the CD (and it is a minor gripe) is that you pretty much have to turn the volume all the way up on your CD player or stereo to hear the music.  Whoever recorded these CDs did so very poorly, and anyone who has this CD is well aware of this problem.  Other than that, however, there are no detractions from the overall quality of Mr. Silvestri's music.<br />The score for &quot;Forrest Gump&quot; is a classic, as the main theme is practically known the world over.  If you are one of the few people who has never listened to this CD, I guarantee you that you will not regret picking up a copy.<br />This is Alan Silvestri at his best, folks; he doesn't get much better that this.

B00005QXXO|4.0|Having seen Radiohead last summer in Chicago, I knew they were awesome live, one of the few bands who can bring studio brilliance to the stage, and I had high hopes when I heard a live cd was being released.<br />What is on the cd is great, but I docked it a star for the compact length of the album, only 8 songs.  They could have EASILY added another 3-4 songs from Kid A/Amnesiac that were mesmerizing live, namely You and Whose Army, Pyramid Song, Packt Like Sardines, or How To Disappear Completely.  The only reason I can think of that they kept it this short is that they will release a dvd next year of an entire show, and they didn't want to let too much out of the bag at this point.<br />What is on the album is excellent though:<br />1. National Anthem:  this song truly transcends the studio version.  Colin Greenwood rules on the bass, providing the twangy foundation for the song, and the keyboard and echo effects make one wonder if they are listening to Dark Side of the Moon.  Thom is his usual great self.<br />2. I Might Be Wrong: the song on the album that most closely matches the studio version, though there is some cool jamming at the end of it.<br />3. Morning Bell: this performance of the song is based on the Kid A version. The song starts out slow and erupts with emotion about 2 minutes in.<br />4. Like Spinning Plates:  Most people will buy this album for two songs, this one and True Love Waits.  I am not a big fan of LSP on Amnesiac, but this song is SO GOOD live.  The piano brings a tenderness to the song, and Thom's voice bleeds with melancholy.  Truly amazing.<br />5. Idioteque:  an interesting change in tempo, following the slow and somber LSP.  The song starts out powerfully with Phil's drumming, along with Ed and Jonny's electronic whirly sounds, and it has an edgier sound than on studio version.  Thom continues his brilliance on vocals.<br />6. Everything In Its Right Place:  another song that has a more atmospheric, dreamy sound live than the studio version. At the end of the song Thom makes things interesting by kicking in the voice modulation/echo effects.<br />7. Dollars and Cents: The rhythm section, Phil and Colin, impress again with the beats.  Another song I am not too crazy about on Amnesiac that comes alive onstage and has some great improvisations.<br />8. True Love Waits:  glad to finally have this on an album.  It is a fitting end, and the highlight, of this live album.  Coincidentally, it is also the most simple, just Thom's captivating voice and an acoustic guitar.  This song really shows the true versatility Radiohead have.  They can move from psychadelic, cutting-edge electronic songs to guitar-based anthems to stripped-down acoustic affairs, and blow us away equally with all of these approaches.<br />This album would have been better with 3 more songs, and way better if they just had released one single concert they thought was particularly good, but at least we finally got a live album out of them.  Get this and enjoy what doesn't come around often enough in the U.S.: live Radiohead.

B00005R2M3|3.0|I'm a huge fan of Shakira's music, which was, previously, all in Spanish.  I have always been impressed with her strong voice and lyrics that were generally not in the mold of the inane and overproduced Latin female pop singers.  On her new album, &quot;Laundry Service,&quot; she deserves credit for trying to write her own lyrics in English, and also for producing the album.  Unfortunately, the songs reflect her relative inexperience with the language and, consequently, lack sophistication.  She is all over the map stylistically (although, come to think of it, her albums in Espanol are kind of the same way), but this is a difficult way to introduce her to the English speaking world. With her (bottle) blond mass of hair and sexy clothes, I'm starting to think she now wants to be Britney Spears instead of the singer-songwriters she says she admires. <br />&quot;Wherever, Whenever&quot; is quite good and probably the first single; &quot;Underneath Your Clothes&quot; isn't bad, neither is &quot;Fool&quot;, but of the rest of the album I truly prefer to hear her songs in Spanish.  I was disappointed that Gloria Estefan's translation of &quot;Ojos Asi&quot; (On this album, &quot;Eyes Like Yours&quot;) loses the magic of the original.<br />I hope Shakira keeps trying because I think she has true star and crossover potential, but it wouldn't hurt for her to collaborate with someone who understands her artistic sensibilities, but can help her craft more meaningful lyrics in English (Brian Eno, Glen Ballard, are you listening?).
B000002O5L|5.0|I'm not sure I go so far as to say this is the best album of Tom Petty's stellar career, but it is very close.  The only one that can make a serious case for being better is Damn the Torpedos, which I do give the nod to, although many of his albums are very good.<br />This album, produced by longtime Petty friend Jeff Lynne, is made of largely lighter stuff than the majority of his work.  Despite the fact that is often viewed as his most commerical album, any limited pop sensibilities is has are more than balanced out by the deceptively meaningful lyrics.  <br />This album also marks Petty's first solo effort after a long stint with the Heartbreake (although all of them make at least one appearance on the album).  <br />Full Moon Fever album opens with probably Petty's best song in Free Fallin'.  It is a largely acoustic coming of age anthem that is among the most beautiful songs he has recorded.  It doesn't miss a beat from there as it heads into the best rocker on the album. &quot;Won't Back Down&quot; is another one of Petty's strongest songs and fits the upbeat tempo of the album perfectly.<br />There is nary a weak moment on the album, although some people argue that it does lose momentum as it nears the end with such tracks as &quot;The Apartment Song&quot; and &quot;Zombie Zoo&quot; (both of which actually number among my favorites).  <br />If you are looking for some of the harder-edged material Petty did earlier in his career, look elsewhere since this album is definitely the most polished and produced album of his career.  Full Moon Fever provides an interesting contrast with the more somber music he would record later in the decade, as well as with the rawer music from earlier in his career.<br />This album is worth a look, and probably more..

B00003CXMG|5.0|~This has got to be The BEST film I have senn in all time. Kate Hudson as Penny Lane, literally shines in every scene.<br />Set in San Diego in the early 1970s, Almost Famous subtly introduces the element of rock'n'roll music as a venue for freedom. Finding moral support in the lyrics of Simon & Garfunkel, 18-year-old Anita (Zooey Deschanel) rebels against her conservative mother Elaine (Frances McDormand). Deciding to leave home, she urges her younger brother William to let himself be influenced~~ by the music of the era. Over the years, William (Patrick Fugit) develops an interest and befriends legendary music critic Lester Bangs (Philip Seymour Hoffman: Flawless, Magnolia, The Talented Mr. Ripley), who asks him to cover a Black Sabbath concert for \\"Creem\\" magazine. His article earns the mature-sounding 15-year-old an assignment from Rolling Stone magazine to join the more accessible \\"Stillwater\\" band and interview lead guitarist Russell Hammond (Billy Crudup) and lead singer~~ Jeff Bebe (Jason Lee) during their \\"Almost Famous\\" concert tour. Postponing his obligations at school and at home, William develops emotional ties with the band and with the coquettish groupie Penny Lane (Kate Hudson), and discovers the contradictions of being a subjective journalist.<br />Almost Famous constructs its plot with effective time constraints which create suspense and establish the film's sense of humor. This is explored within the arena of William's responsibilities toward his~~ editor (who thinks the writer he has hired over the phone is much older) and his mother (who wishes her boy is mature enough to resist peer pressure and drugs, but young enough to obey her). Both the editor and the mother, who require that William constantly check back with them and who impose deadlines (to submit the article outline or to return home), communicate with the protagonist via the phone throughout most of the film. Still, rather than interrupt the boy's tour/trip with the band, the~~ editor/mother interludes emphasize the main character's inability to escape from duty. The comedy rises from William's efforts to be seen as a free adult --a status the band members claim to have reached-- while he struggles with his evident inexperience. Never quite reaching a dramatic point, Almost Famous maintains a comfortable level of seriousness as it explores the main character's doubts and decisions in relation to his role as \\"The Enemy\\", or the critic who \\"writes what he sees.\\"~~ Not letting his perceptions be influenced by the illusion of friendship, nor letting them deny the validity of his subjective reality, the protagonist finds freedom in those attempts that \\"almost\\" fail or \\"almost succeed\\". In this sense, Almost Famous finds a temperate --almost happy-- middle ground in its treatment of such commonly temperamental issues as sex, drugs and rock'n'roll.~/mother interludes emphasize the main character's inability to escape from duty. B00005NIDK|4.0|THe first track I heard from this album was &quot;In the Presence of&quot;, and I cringed when I heard it. I was looking forward to Yes' orchestral collaboration, but if this tepid work was the product, then count me out! Then I heard the rest of the tracks, and now I know that the first impression of an energyless album was incorrect. I'll go track-by-track in review, and give each a rating out of five..<br />(1) Magnification (4/5)- a great way to start off the album. Perhaps just a touch long (about 7 minutes), but it's catchy, and you'll be singing along to it in no time. <br />(2) Spirit of Survival (5/5) - the second-best track on the album, and a classic Yes song in its own right. Starts out with Jon in depths-of-space mode, then rocks hard for the next 8 minutes or so. Strong backup vocals from Chris.<br />(3) Don't Go (4/5) - This is getting some mixed reviews from fans, but I think it's an excellent song. We won't hear it on the radio, but it's a catchy song, and is more down-to-earth than Jon's usual lyrics.<br />(4) Give Love Each Day (3/5) - This is where things start to go downhill a bit. The orchestral intro is beautiful (on par with some of the best movie score arranging in the past few years), but the song really doesn't go anywhere. Pretty, but it won't stick with you for long.<br />(5)Can You Imagine (3/5) - Chris originally wrote this song in the early 80's, if I remember correctly, and it shows. It would have been an excellent addition to BIG GENERATOR, and here it's a great showcase for Chris' distinct vocal style, but it's a waypoint, not a destination.<br />(6) We Agree (3.5/5) - I just can't get into this song. I have a feeling it's one that will grow on me, but for now, I can't give it a higher rating.<br />(7) Soft As a Dove (2/5) - Ugh. The lyrics are somewhat touching, but it's like cotton candy - it melts away, leaving nothing behind. On the wrong side of sappy.<br />(8) Dreamtime (5/5) - NOW we're talking! Instant classic Yes track. Driving, vigourous, the orchestra keeping up - when Jon arpeggios down with the violins following, it brings a chill to the spine. Chris sounding like an avenging spirit. A Quality 10 minute piece, right up there with recent Yes classics like Homeworld and New Languages.<br />(9) ITPO (3.5/5) - Not so much as a comedown as a change of pace, it loses a half-point for letting the sappy gremlin to get ahold of Jon's pen. Musically, it's very textured and interesting, not as monotonous as on first hearing.<br />(10) Time is Time (?/5) - Perhaps it's bad that this song doesn't even make an impression. Sounds like the closing credits for a TV show.<br />Even though I've given short shrift to some of the songs above, this is still one of the best albums this year. In short, if Yes wants to be heard on the radio, they should lead off with a four-and-a-half minute edit of Magnification, then follow up with Don't Go. Not that that will happen, but it's too bad that an album this good will undoubtedly disappear into the back bins of record stores.<br />All in all, it's great that a band with Yes' longevity is still trying new things and making new music. Keep it up, guys!

B00005QXXO|4.0|Considering how some jaded critics said how impenetrable Kid A and Amnesiac are, the live reworkings of seven of the albums' songs on I Might Be Wrong are a remarkable statement by Radiohead. Not only do Radiohead deftly recreate the sound of their past two albums in a live setting, they actually make all the songs sound better than the studio versions.<br />I Might Be Wrong is less a live album than a remix EP, and thankfully, the crowd noise is kept to a minimum in the mix so listeners can enjoy hearing Thom Yorke, Johnny Greenwood, and Company deliver blistering, desperately urgent versions of 'The National Anthem', 'I Might Be Wrong', and 'Idioteque'. The quickened pace of the title track alone is chilling, while 'Idioteque' works strangely well as a stadium rocker. More downtempo songs like 'Morning Bell' and 'Dollars And Cents' showcase the band's skill at subtle accompaniment to Yorke's impassioned vocals. 'Everything In Its Right Place' posesses as many kooky effects as the studio version, but also an all-too-human flub at the beginning, and the band hardly miss a step and begin a few bars later.<br />The most startling improvement is on 'Like Spinning Plates', a song which I originally considered to be Amnesiac's worst. Instead of being an indecipherable miasma of loops and effects, the song is given spare treatment, in the form of a piano ballad, and the result is enthralling. The previously unreleased track 'True Love Waits', which goes as far back as 1995, makes a long-overdue appearance, in atypically simple form, just Yorke and his guitar, and compared to Kid Amnesiac's esoteric lyrics, the song is startlingly honest.<br />I Might Be Wrong is so surprisingly good that it makes one wish for a complete live recording, either on cd or dvd. Besides, many of Radiohead's fans, like myself, live in cities where they'll never, ever visit. Radiohead is a terrific live band, and proof that you don't need big power chords to connect with the audience, and this new live collection leaves you thirsty for more.
B00005Q66T|5.0|So you are a basic Madonna fanatic fan if you purchase this cd. Why? With two greatest hits packages already in stores, 1990s Immaculate Collection and 1995s Something to Remember, Madonna has released most of her best works and then some.<br />With GHV2 Madonna is releasing her hits since the early 90s. What is missing is new releases. Unlike the previous collections which resulted in new tracks, GHV2 does not contain any new material.<br />Drawing heavily on 1994s Bedtime Stories and 1998s Ray of Light, GHV2 showcases a Madonna who has evolved from dance pop smash queen to reniasance woman!<br />Starting things off is 1994s hit, Deeper and Deeper. Kind of a metaphor for the Madonna today. Hits like Secret, Human Nature, Bedtime Story, right up through Ray of Light hits and with her latest endeavor, Music.<br />What can you say? Critics alike will be alarmed at the omission of hits like American Pie, Nothing Really Matters, and You Must Love Me, they can find those hits on other albums.<br />What does this CD really matter to us fans, it is a chance to her latest round of hits to be included on one cd. <br />Interesting to note is the liner notes and nothing from Mad herself. B00005QK3W|4.0|Growing up among old Beatles records, I couldn't help but develop a deep appreciation of the Beatles' catalogue, but Paul McCartney's solo albums never really did it for me; however, instead of jumping on the Bash Paul bandwagon and assuming a false hipster stance of how he totally lost his edge over the years, I tended to feel good for the guy. After all, he had a great marriage, happy kids, the money to live the way he wanted with minimal fuss, and a pretty successful solo career. Why need grit when you're so happy?<br />However, the passing of his longtime wife Linda has seemed to make his music sound more passionate. His covers album, Run Devil Run, was a more intense return to live-to-tape rock &amp; roll, and his first album of new material since Linda's death continues in the same pattern. There's a grittiness present on Driving Rain that I haven't heard from Macca in years, a urgency that's aided in part by his good backing band of younger musicians, and his lyrics seem to be either speaking to Linda, his new fiancee Heather, or both, like he's trying to seek some kind of redemption.<br />Driving Rain is overloaded with songs, which muddles things up a bit, but the highlights are fantastic. The opening tracks 'Lonely Road' and 'From A Lover To A Friend' set the tone for the entire album, with the latter's refrain &quot;From a lover to a friend/let me love again&quot; being some of the most heartbreakingly personal lyrics Paul has ever written. 'Your Loving Flame' is a classic Macca ballad, while 'Riding Into Jaipur' is a bit of a departure into George Harrison territory. Best of all are two songs: The rambunctious ten-minute 'Rinse The Raindrops' is as adventurous a song McCartney's ever written, remarkably not as self-indulgent as you'd think, and with fabulous vocals by Paul and tight musicianship by his backing band. 'Heather', though, is one of the best songs McCartney has ever written, utterly gorgeous, and proof that he's found another muse.<br />There's the usual filler that is always present in a Macca album...some lyrics were a cringeworthy (&quot;1-2-3-4-5, let's go for a drive&quot;...sheesh), and the jingoistic song 'Freedom' that was tacked on at the end is catchy, but ultimately rings hollow. Paul could have done better. Still, the Goofy Paul moments are keprt to a minimum, and the rest of Driving Rain holds up very well. It's quite a good album, one of Paul's best.

B00005JKHP|5.0|Finally, it all makes sense.  Star Trek fans should forget about the critics and go and get this DVD.  The director's cut has several new and enhanced scenes, a terrific score, and revealing commentaries.  It's a shame the theatrical version wasn't edited right when the film first came out.  But all should be forgiven with this widescreen director's edition.  This is a movie that justifies Dolby surround sound and the extra features of DVD. Fans who don't have a DVD player will surely want to get one.
0345413377|5.0|There are two kinds of great stories -- those that fit seamlessly into the body of thought and make you wonder why no one thought of it before, and those that are remarkably imaginative and compelling and make you wonder how the author thought it up at all. Pullman's trilogy fits into the latter category.  He is a fine writer -- balancing multiple story lines that interconnect and support each other; each character is well drawn, complex and believable; situations are dramatic and interesting.<br /><br />This final installment of Pullman's His Dark Materials trilogy is not disappointing.  It lives up to the preceding volumes, which is a rarity in serial publications (even Tolkien fell down a bit with Return of the King).  I was prepared for a rotten ending after reading many criticisms of it in the reviews here, but I liked the ending -- bittersweet, tragic and hopeful all at once. I would say that the only thing I didn't like was that Lyra slept through one-third of the book!  Without giving any spoilers I will say that there are several scenes that are as emotionally packed as anything I've read.<br /><br />Two notes:  (1) People who DO put spoilers into their reviews should warn or label them as such beforehand.  (2) Frankly, zealotry is tiresome, and it would be nice if commentaries did not have to include reviewers' belief systems. Can't you just relax and read for enjoyment? This book is in the *fantasy* genre. Open your mind a little bit and don't be so threatened by ideas.
B00005QXXO|5.0|An amazing live recording from an amazing band.  Everything on this EP is album worthy.  Unlike most live recordings, the crowd noise is kept extremely quiet, and the result is beautiful alternate versions of the best stuff from Kid A and Amnesiac.  Everything in its Right Place has an awesome new opening, and ends on a beautifully placid note that makes you loose yourself in the song even more than the Kid A version.  The National Anthem has a more distorted, faster bass which really peps up the song.  It is missing the brass section, so it looses a bit of the &quot;Art Rock&quot;ness of it, but it's still very powerful.  The highlight of this EP, however, is the piano/moog version of Like Spinning Plates.  Unlike the choppy, confusing Amnesiac version, the true beauty of this song's progression can finally be realized, and it is breathtaking.  It alone justifies a purchase.  I do wish Radiohead would've thrown in about 5 more tracks and released a complete live album, but this is still an unexpected pleasure, and one of my favorite live records ever.

In my mind, there is no &quot;filler&quot;, only great original songs.  I think it's fantastic that he can sound like so many people on one album. I like Jay Farrar on &quot;Sebastopol&quot;, but he is so one dimensional by comparison.  Now for the best part, I get to go see Ryan on 12/7 LIVE!
B00005QK3W|5.0|The first thing I noticed about Driving Rain is Pauls bass playing, the man is just so innovative on the instrument.  It's good to hear his bass more dominant in the mix, on so many of his albums the bass is buried so deep.  Paul is rocking just listen to Lonely Road,  Driving Rain,  About You,  and Rinse The Raindrops.  He's also soulful check out Tiny Bubble,  and Back In The Sunshine Again.  Paul is the master of variety and this album won't let you down.  The stand out track on the entire album is Your Loving Flame, a power ballad if there ever was one!  It's been a long time since Paul wrote a ballad this strong, it deserves the full treatment (promotion, video, etc).  Driving Rain finds Paul carrying on with his greatness, and Your Loving Flame is one of Pauls best, a definite McCartney classic!!
